title: Services
body: Services

title: Overview
body: FA provides various services to clients. Services need to be separately requested and agreed upon with FA and services are invoiced based on time and material. The first step in the service request process is to agree on the scope and delivery timelines together with FA. Available services are described below. The table below describes optional (o=optional) services for each plan size.

title: Overview
body: *Allowed customizations depend on the plan size.

title: Data migration
body: Clients can acquire data migration as an optional service from FA or a recommended third party. If FA is doing the data migration, the client needs to provide the following information for FA to estimate the required effort:

title: Data migration
body: Amount of data that needs to be migrated in CSV or XLSX format

title: Data migration
body: Number of clients

title: Data migration
body: Number of portfolios

title: Data migration
body: Number of transactions

title: Data migration
body: Number of securities

title: Data migration
body: Security types that the client operates with

title: Data migration
body: Start date from which transactions need to be migrated

title: Data migration
body: Contact person for data-related queries

title: Data migration
body: After FA receives the data and related details, we will organize review sessions with the client and provide an initial estimate of the effort and schedule. The migration work is done based on time and material.

title: Customization
body: The FA platform provides flexibility for customizations. Customization options depend on the plan size that the client has selected. A list of customization options for different plans is available in Plans. For detailed descriptions of different customization options, see Customizability.

title: Training
body: FA provides various materials for clients to learn about the features and solutions we offer:

title: Training
body: Helpdesk - FA product features and client-specific documentation

title: Training
body: FA Documentation

title: Training
body: General documentation and FA standard business solutions

title: Training
body: Developer Guide - developer-oriented instructions

title: Training
body: Developer documentation - developer-oriented instructions

title: Training
body: Training focuses on the general features of the FA Platform. If the client needs training sessions and would like to have an FA consultant running the sessions, we can deliver this as a service. In such a case, the client should inform FA about the subject of the training. The consultant will then prepare, schedule, and run the training as requested.

title: Training
body: By default, FA organizes the training online. We can also provide training on client premises if needed. In this case, the client is invoiced for the resulting time and travel expenses.

title: Workshop
body: Workshops focus on client-specific business needs and workflows. Workshops can be arranged upon request.

title: Workshop
body: The client needs to inform FA about the topic and background of the business workflow or issue that the workshop is meant to cover. An FA consultant will then prepare for the topic and arrange the workshop. After the workshop, FA will summarize the outcome of the meeting for the client.

title: Workshop
body: By default, FA runs workshops online. We can also provide workshops on client premises if needed. In this case, the client is invoiced for the resulting time and travel expenses.

title: Other consultation
body: If the client needs consultation, they should reach out to FA. We will then evaluate if an FA consultant or an FA partner could provide the requested consultation.

title: Support
body: Support

title: Support
body: Support means a service provided by the FA for the client to report FA system related technical issues and to request FA system related usage guidance. Support is provided for the client's trained main users. Support is offered via FA Helpdesk which acts as a single point of contact to all support related matters. FA’s support serves clients during default business hours Mon-Fri 0800-1700 CET according to SLA defined in the agreement. SLA applies to production environment and after the customer has gone live with the FA system. The scope of the support depends on the support types included in the Plan. Different support types are described below. Services can be requested via Service Request. Please see Services for more information.

title: Self Service Support
body: Self Service support includes the client access to all documentation of FA Platform. Based on documentation (FA Helpdesk and FA Documentation), customers can independently browse/search the documentation, find answers and apply instructions to their questions.

title: Standard Support
body: Standard support provides general assistance on product usage related questions and a forum for product related issue reporting. The Standard support is provided by FA’s Customer Support team via FA Helpdesk ticketing system.

title: Consultative Support
body: Consultative support provides case specific assistance on product usage related questions. Consultative support can be requested via FA Helpdesk ticketing system. The Consultative support is initiated via FA HelpDesk and if needed followed up by online calls. Consultative support is provided by FA’s Customer Support or Professional Services team.

title: Developer support
body: Developer support provides assistance on product customizability related questions. Product customizability options are described in the Customizability. Developer support is initiated via FA Helpdesk ticketing system and if needed followed up by online calls. Developer support is provided by FA’s Professional Services team.

title: SLA
body: FA Customer Services provides assistance and processes customer requests according to service level agreement which includes guaranteed response and resolution times, based on requests' priority classification and subscription Plan.

title: SLA
body: Request priorities are classified as:

title: SLA
body: Urgent request = issue is preventing the whole production

title: SLA
body: High request = issue is seriously impeding production

title: SLA
body: Normal request = issue is impeding production or preventing test usage

title: SLA
body: Low request = issue is general question, improvement or new feature request, or otherwise not impeding production by any means, has a workaround

title: SLA
body: Priorities are objectively evaluated and can be adjusted by Customer Services.

title: Support 1st Response time / 1st Resolution time
body: Hours are measured during default business hours Mon-Fri 0800-1700 CET.

title: Support 1st Response time / 1st Resolution time
body: Response time means that the request is in progress or resolution suggestion is given by Customer Services. Response times, per subscription level, are defined in the matrix below. Resolution times are included in the “Advance” plan only. First Resolution time is the first time that an Agent sets a ticket to solved, Full Resolution is when a ticket is fully resolved and the customer does not re-open it with further questions or concerns. The time is specified as the time between a ticket creation time and the first timestamp the ticket was marked as solved. When the request is set as solved, pending, or on-hold, which stops SLA calculation, when for example a workaround, instruction, schedule for an improvement, new feature, or product defect has been provided.

title: Reporting
body: SLA reporting on requests and actual availability is provided according to Service Management meeting schedules per subscription Plan.

title: Customer Relationship Manager with Service Management meetings
body: Customer Relationship Management function is part of Customer Services and is included in all subscription Plans as in the matrix below. It consists of service management meetings, reporting, info about new functionalities and features, and that helps customers to use and utilize FA more efficiently in their business.

title: Customer Relationship Manager with Service Management meetings
body: All customers are invited to new feature and version release online webinars, user group meetings facilitated by FA, and user summits.

title: Guaranteed uptime
body: FA has 24/7 server monitoring with system availability uptime SLA as:

title: Guaranteed uptime
body: The following situations are excluded from the calculation of availability time:

title: Guaranteed uptime
body: Time spent on the installation, alteration, or maintenance measures agreed upon by the Parties.

title: Guaranteed uptime
body: Unavailability caused by factors outside of our reasonable control, including any force majeure event or Internet access or related problems beyond the demarcation point of the Supplier

title: Guaranteed uptime
body: That being resulted from not following the guidelines described in the material or support provided by the Supplier

title: Guaranteed uptime
body: Other Accepted Downtime situations

title: Guaranteed uptime
body: The service is considered available and up when the user is able to sign-in to the system and access all available applications. The system is considered available even if:

title: Guaranteed uptime
body: The data is not up-to-date as the report updates processes are running in the background

title: Guaranteed uptime
body: The system does not function as expected due to an error in the system or in the data

title: Guaranteed uptime
body: The system is unusually slow to respond due to network issues outside FA

title: Guaranteed uptime
body: Access to 3rd party application, service, or data is prevented due to reasons outside FA

title: Service level credits per Plan
body: Credits can be refunded for only one of the SLAs that has higher percentage.

title: Uptime SLA
body: The Availability Window is 24/7/365

title: Uptime SLA
body: Actual Availability = (Availability Window during the calendar month rounded to full minutes – (Downtime during the calendar month rounded to full minutes - Accepted Downtime during the calendar month rounded to full minutes)) / Availability Window during the calendar month rounded to full minutes *100.

title: Request SLA
body: Request SLA refund applies only to “Urgent” and “High” priority requests and is measured monthly.

title: FA Client Portal
body: FA Client Portal is an app that provides access to investment information for your clients. The app runs in the web browser on desktop and mobile devices.

title: FA Client Portal
body: Overview provides a quick glance at the client’s assets, profit and available cash. The user can view the aggregated data from all portfolios or for a chosen portfolio.

title: FA Client Portal
body: Holdings view shows the client’s investments.

title: FA Client Portal
body: Transactions view shows the client’s transactions for a chosen time period. The user can view the transaction details by tapping a transaction.

title: FA Client Portal
body: Orders view shows the client’s trade orders. For each order in the list, the user can view the total market value and unrealized profit since start. The user can cancel trade orders that haven't been sent forward for execution.

title: FA Client Portal
body: Documents view shows documents for the selected portfolio or subportfolio. If the user selects total investments, all contact and portfolio documents are shown.

title: FA Client Portal
body: Trading view allows the user to browse securities on the markets and create buy trade orders.

title: FA Client Portal
body: Deposits and Withdrawals allow the user to deposit money to the portfolio cash account or withdraw money from it.

title: FA Client Portal
body: Contact us view shows your company's contacts.

title: Related links
body: FA Client Portal

title: Related links
body: FA Client Portal setup in FA Admin guide

title: Related links
body: Customize FA Client Portal in FA Developer guide

title: Trading Connector
body: Trading Connector

title: Overview
body: FA’s Trading Connector automates your trade order management by sending orders to your preferred trading venue. You can thus monitor the status and execution information of your trade orders in real time.

title: Functionality
body: Send trade orders from FA to a trading platform of your choice

title: Functionality
body: Send trade orders via a trading integration - select trade orders in FA and send them forward to your trading platform. When sending orders via a trading integration, your orders are executed outside of FA. You can use one of the supported trading connectors, as long as the connector supports sending trade orders. You can also automate sending trade orders based on a schedule and custom criteria. For example, you can automatically send all buy and sell orders with status "Accepted" forward every day at 16:00.

title: Functionality
body: Connect to multiple trading platforms simultaneously - you can connect to multiple trading platforms at the same time, and you can route your trade orders to suitable trading connectors. For example, you can route your fund orders to Euroclear FundsPlace, while your stock and ETF orders are routed to Infront. You can also automate the trade order routing to the correct trading platform - automatic order routing requires additional configuration.

title: Functionality
body: Automatically receive execution information about your orders from a trading platform

title: Functionality
body: Receive order status updates and execution information on sent orders - trading connectors support automatically updating the trade order status and execution/payment information to trade orders you have sent forward with one of our trading connectors. The exact frequency and content of these updates vary from connector to connector.

title: Functionality
body: Receive drop copy session messages - Receive near real-time information about trades executed in other trading platforms. The incoming feed of orders updates or creates new trade orders in FA. Drop copy sessions are supported in FIX formats only for certain connections (see the Supported formats and service providers table).

title: Functionality
body: Send execution information on orders received in FA

title: Functionality
body: Send order updates on the trade orders received by your fund - select trade orders executed in FA and send trade order update messages and execution information from FA to your fund distributor. You can use one of the supported trading connectors, as long as the connector supports receiving trade orders. You can also automate sending trade order updates based on a schedule and custom criteria.

title: Supported formats and service providers
body: To use the Trading Connector, you need to have access to one or more of the supported trading connectors listed below. Some counterparties require onboarding with a separate cost.

title: Configuring Analytics columns in Preferences
body: You can manage your own tailored Analytics+ columns under Content and translations Preferences.

title: Configuring Analytics columns in Preferences
body: Columns based on key figures are fairly easy to add: just define a name for your column and select which key figure you want to use. Custom columns based on a formula require a bit more effort: type “analytics.” to select an existing column you want to use and embed it in your mathematical formula. In addition, you can configure how group level values are calculated (such as calculating group levels with weighted average, rounding up) and override default formatting of column values.

title: Configuring Analytics columns in Preferences
body: Changes in tailored columns and formulas are audited - user audit (system audit before FA 3.9) tracks changes users make in Analytics+ column Preferences. Every time a user makes a change to a tailored column, system audit contains a message ”User [username] created/changed/deleted Analytics+ custom column definition [code]”. These entries allow you to track whether the contents of your custom columns change. (Available from FA 3.8 onward)

title: Step 1 - Basic column info
body: When starting to create a new Analytics+ column, first define the basic column information.

title: Step 1 - Basic column info
body: Available settings include:

title: Step 1 - Basic column info
body: Select how you want to define the column

title: Step 1 - Basic column info
body: Select whether you want to create a tailored column Based on a security key figure or Based on a formula. This determines what kind of fields are visible for you to define your column.

title: Step 1 - Basic column info
body: Code

title: Step 1 - Basic column info
body: Define a unique code for your column. We recommend using only alphanumeric values (i.e. letters a-z and numbers 0-9, no spaces or special characters). Column code is used to identify the column programmatically, and you cannot modify it after you save your column.

title: Step 1 - Basic column info
body: Name

title: Step 1 - Basic column info
body: Define a name for your column. Column name is used to show the column throughout the application, for example as a column heading.

title: Step 1 - Basic column info
body: In addition to the required information, you can accompany your tailored Analytics+ columns with a description and a link, allowing you to explain the content of your column in more detail. Description and link you define in Preferences are shown in Analytics+ when you mouse-over the column when selecting columns, allowing you to more easily select the columns you need. (Available from FA 3.8 onward)

title: Step 1 - Basic column info
body: Related settings include:

title: Step 1 - Basic column info
body: Description

title: Step 1 - Basic column info
body: Free text field to describe the content of the column, shown as text when selecting columns in Analytics+.

title: Step 1 - Basic column info
body: Link

title: Step 1 - Basic column info
body: Provide a link for more information on the column, shown as a link when selecting columns in Analytics+.

title: Step 2 - Select the key figure or define the formula
body: Depending on how you selected to define the column, you either have an option to select the key figure you want to use in your column, or define the formula for your column.

title: Step 2 - Select the key figure or define the formula
body: Your options are either to:

title: Step 2 - Select the key figure or define the formula
body: Select the security key figure you want to use as a column

title: Step 2 - Select the key figure or define the formula
body: When you are creating a column based on a key figure, just select the security key figure you want to use as a column. The dropdown lists all security key figures you have defined in Key figure Preferences for securities.

title: Step 2 - Select the key figure or define the formula
body: Define the formula

title: Step 2 - Select the key figure or define the formula
body: When you are creating a column based on formula, define your formula within the available area. Your formula will be evaluated when you save it, and only valid formulas are saved. In case your formula is invalid, you will be prompted with details on what in your formula fails. Formula editor provides you with different options to define your formula:

title: Step 2 - Select the key figure or define the formula
body: Use existing Analytics+ columns in your formula. Type in "analytics." in the formula editor, and the system will provide you with a list of existing Analytics+ columns to choose from. Columns are listed with their codes (which the formula expects), but you can see the column name in the description on the right to help you identify the column you are looking for. You can use the existing columns in mathematical calculations, for example to sum, multiply and divide existing column values to derive new columns.

title: Step 2 - Select the key figure or define the formula
body: Use certain security details in your formula. Type in "security." in the formula editor, and the system will provide you with a list of security details to choose from. Security-related columns are listed with their codes (which the formula expects). Not all Security fields are bound into Analytics+. You can use security details just to show them in Analytics+, or to use them as part of your calculations.

title: Step 2 - Select the key figure or define the formula
body: Program a more complex formula. In addition, you can use Groovy or Java to program more complex formulas, and for example to use the indexed return data the whole analysis is based on as input to your formula. If you are interested in more complex formulas, contact FA for assistance.

title: Step 3 - Select how to calculate values on group level
body: After you have defined the content for your column, you can decide whether and how your column is calculated on the group level. By default, your own Analytics+ columns are only calculated for the security level (e.g. shown only for individual positions), but with the following settings you can tell to the system how your columns should be calculated on the group level (e.g. if you have grouped you analysis "By type", how should the column value be calculated on the security type level).

title: Step 3 - Select how to calculate values on group level
body: Whether to calculate values on group levels depends on your column's content: for example, "Market value in security currency" doesn't make sense when calculated on group levels (you might otherwise end up summing up market value in different currencies), whereas different ratings can be calculated on group levels as weighted average (and for example, you might want to always round risk-related ratings up for a conservative take on your analysis).

title: Step 3 - Select how to calculate values on group level
body: Use the following settings to control how the system should calculate values on the group levels:

title: Step 3 - Select how to calculate values on group level
body: Select how to calculate values on group levels

title: Step 3 - Select how to calculate values on group level
body: You have different options to determine whether and how values are calculated on group levels. Consider the options carefully in order to find the best option for your column and the content you show with it.

title: Step 3 - Select how to calculate values on group level
body: Do not show values on group levels (default). Column values are shown only on individual positions on the position level, and not calculated to any group level. For such columns, the group level is shown as empty.

title: Step 3 - Select how to calculate values on group level
body: Calculate group level as the direct sum of lower levels. Group levels are calculated as a sum of the levels below it, i.e. any numerical column value from a "child" level will be summed up to the "parent" level. All group levels are simply the sum of the values from levels below.

title: Step 3 - Select how to calculate values on group level
body: Calculate group level as the weighted average of lower levels. Group levels are calculated as a weighted average of the levels below it, i.e. any numerical column value from a "child" level is weighted and summed up to the "paren"t level, using corresponding "share of parent" as the weight. The weighted average is calculated with the value in the "Share of parent" column.

title: Step 3 - Select how to calculate values on group level
body: Calculate group level as the weighted average using the absolute value of the weights. Same as above but using the absolute value of the weight. This means that negative positions will have a positive weight.

title: Step 3 - Select how to calculate values on group level
body: Apply formula also on group level. Only relevant if you are defining a column based on a formula. This applies the formula on the group level instead of calculating group level values from values on the lower levels. For example, you have a formula that sums up two column's values (x + y). If you select to calculate the group level from lower levels, this would mean the system calculates x + y on all your position, and then sums those up to the group level (e.g. security type level value is the sum from all positions' x + y values). However, if you apply formula on group level, it will take the x and y values directly as they have been calculated for the group level, and use those group level values to calculate x + y. Difference is whether you first calculate x + y on all positions and then sum those up, or whether you first calculate x and y on your group level, and then sum those group level figures up.

title: Step 3 - Select how to calculate values on group level
body: Select how to round values on the group level OR what category to use for categorized figures

title: Step 3 - Select how to calculate values on group level
body: When working with numerical column values (if your column returns an integer or if you have a categorized key figure associated with a numeric value for calculations) and you have selected one of the "Calculate group level as..." options from above, you can control how rounding is handled. You can choose between "normal rounding rules", "always round up" or "always round down" - consider which rounding is most relevant for your column.

title: Step 3 - Select how to calculate values on group level
body: Round based on normal rounding rules (half up) OR use the nearest category. Rounds values according to normal rounding rules, using half up. For example, 1.51 (everything greater or equal to 1.5) will be rounded to 2 if your column value is an integer, or to B (2) if you have a categorized key figure with options 1=A, 2=B.

title: Step 3 - Select how to calculate values on group level
body: Always round up OR use the nearest bigger category. Always rounds up to the next closest value. For example, 1.21 (everything greater than 1) will be rounded to 2 if your column value is an integer, or to B (2) if you have a categorized key figure with options 1=A, 2=B.

title: Step 3 - Select how to calculate values on group level
body: Always round down OR use the nearest smaller category. Always rounds down to the next closest value.For example, 1.71 (everything less than 2) will be rounded to 1 if your column value is an integer, or to A (1) if you have a categorized key figure with options 1=A, 2=B.

title: Step 3 - Select how to calculate values on group level
body: Select how to aggregate children without a value

title: Step 3 - Select how to calculate values on group level
body: Allows you to control how to manage levels without a value when you have selected one of the "Calculate group level as..." options from above. That is, how you want to calculate a group level value in for your column if one of your positions is missing the value you are showing.

title: Step 3 - Select how to calculate values on group level
body: Aggregate up only if all children have a value. Group level values are not calculated if any "child" on the lower level is missing a value.

title: Step 3 - Select how to calculate values on group level
body: Aggregate up with default value 0 if a child doesn't have a value. Group level values are calculated assuming 0 for any missing value, and using that in the group level calculation.

title: Step 4 - Override default formatting
body: Finally, you can override the default formatting of your column if needed. By default, the system determines a default formatting for your column based on the key figure you are using, or the Analytics+ columns you are using in your formula. However, you might want to change how many decimals are shown, you might want to format your value as a percentage, or you might want to apply a date formatting to dates.

title: Step 4 - Override default formatting
body: Use the following settings to override formatting:

title: Step 4 - Override default formatting
body: Do you want to override the default formatting?

title: Step 4 - Override default formatting
body: Select from No, use default formatting and Yes, override formatting. If you chose to override the default formatting, more fields appear for you to define the format. It is recommended to use default formatting when possible, and only override formatting if there is a valid need to override the default.

title: Step 4 - Override default formatting
body: Define the format to use

title: Step 4 - Override default formatting
body: Allows you to define the format the system should use to format your column's values. Define the formatting according to the type of your column - if your column is a number, use a relevant number format, or if you column is a date, use a relevant date format. Define the format the same way as in Date and decimal formats Preferences. For example, you can use "#,##0" never to show any decimals, or "#,##0.00" to always show two decimals.

title: Step 4 - Override default formatting
body: Value type

title: Step 4 - Override default formatting
body: Indicates what type of a figure your column returns. You cannot change this, but it is automatically determined by the system. This is especially useful when overriding the formatting: this type indicates whether you are overriding a number formatting or for example a date formatting. You can also use this column to check the output of your formula. For columns based on key figures, this field tells you the key figure type.

title: Step 4 - Override default formatting
body: Select how to align the column content in tables

title: Step 4 - Override default formatting
body: Allows you to select between Align right and Align left. By default, columns with type string are aligned left, and column with other types (i.e. numbers and dates) are aligned right - you can use this column to override this behavior.

title: Portfolio management
body: FA's core is a transaction-based portfolio management system. Positions are calculated based on transactions. When saving a transaction, position data is updated and report data recalculation is triggered.

title: Portfolio management
body: In this Portfolio Management section, all the relevant portfolio management components are introduced. In addition, this section describes helper tools for linked to these components.

title: Contacts
body: The portfolio usually belongs to one customer. These system operators are called "contacts" in FA (customer, treasurer, custodian and others).

title: Contacts
body: Add a contact

title: Portfolios and positions
body: The portfolio in FA is a basket of investments that can hold stocks, bonds, cash, and other items. These positions have amount (units), purchase price and market price. FA is a transaction-based system, so these positions are built on transactions that are recorded to the system.

title: Securities
body: In FA the term "security" refers to a financial instrument that has some monetary value.

title: Market prices
body: Market price is the value that an asset acquires in the market or the value that an investment firm assigns to a particular security. In FA, these prices are used to value positions.

title: Add key figures
body: You can use key figures as indicators to store information about securities, contacts, and portfolios and view the information as columns in different search views and in Analytics+. For Analytics+, key figures need to be configured separately (see Configuring Analytics columns in Preferences).

title: Add key figures
body: You can view existing key figures and add new ones in Preference. It is possible to modify existing key figure definitions, except the hard-coded security and portfolio key figure definitions.

title: Add key figures
body: To define a new key figure, do the following:

title: Add key figures
body: Go to Preference → Content and translations → Key figures.

title: Add key figures
body: Click Add new key figure.

title: Add key figures
body: Fill in the fields. For field descriptions, see Key figures in FA Back.

title: Add key figures
body: Click Save.

title: Modify key figure definitions
body: You can modify key figure definitions after saving. However, if you modify an existing key figure that already has values stored for contacts, portfolios, or securities, the values are preserved but may not be modified anymore. For example, if you change a key figure from "contact" to "portfolio", you cannot modify the key figure values for contacts.

title: Corporate action types
body: Corporate action types

title: Capital call
body: The capital call corporate action allows you to easily mass-create capital call transactions on all your investors who have committed into your selected security, such as a private equity fund.

title: Capital call
body: For a capital call, define the capital call as a percentage from the investor’s total commitment into the selected security. The capital call corporate action calculates the amount for the transaction with the capital call % you define and the total commitment from the position of the chosen security in the portfolio, and uses the unit price per share defined in the corporate action as the unit price in calculating the trade amount of the created transaction.

title: Capital call
body: The capital call corporate action can be recorded to the system through the Corporate action window with the following information (a star indicates a mandatory field):

title: Capital call
body: Security*

title: Capital call
body: The security the capital call is created to. The total commitment of this security in the portfolio together with the capital call % will determine the amount of the capital call transaction created.

title: Capital call
body: Currency

title: Capital call
body: The currency the capital call is created with. By default the dividend currency is the security’s currency. When the currency of the capital call is set to other than the security’s currency, the capital transaction is recorded to your portfolios so that the capital call is calculated in the capital call currency and converted appropriately to security currency with the defined exchange rate.

title: Capital call
body: Capital call %

title: Capital call
body: The capital call %, i.e. how much out of the total commitment into the selected security is called. The percentage you define here times the total commitment from the position of the chosen security in the portfolio determine the amount of the created transaction.

title: Capital call
body: Enter a number in the field, for example, "50".

title: Capital call
body: Unit price per share

title: Capital call
body: The unit price per share. This value will become the unit price of the created transaction.

title: Capital call
body: Capital call ex-date*

title: Capital call
body: The capital call ex-date. The capital call is calculated based on the total commitment of security in the portfolio on the dividend ex-date. This date will become the transaction date of the created transaction.

title: Capital call
body: Settlement date

title: Capital call
body: The settlement date of the capital call, i.e. when the capital call is actually paid to the portfolio. This date will become the settlement date of the created transaction.

title: Capital call
body: Transaction type

title: Capital call
body: The transaction type for the transactions to be created (if recording capital calls, select "PE - Capital call" or similar).

title: Capital call
body: A new corporate action is created with the OK button below the corporate action information. Remember to run the corporate action to your portfolio(s) in order to create appropriate transactions to your portfolios.

title: Capital return
body: The capital return corporate action can be mainly used as a tool for recording capital returns to your portfolios.

title: Capital return
body: The capital return corporate action takes the amount for the transactions created from the position of the chosen security in the portfolio, and uses the capital return per share defined in the corporate action as the unit price in calculating the trade amount of the created transaction.

title: Capital return
body: The capital return can be recorded to the system through the Corporate action window with the following information (a star indicates a mandatory field):

title: Capital return
body: Security*

title: Capital return
body: The security the capital return is payed for. The amount of this security in the portfolio will determine the amount of the transaction created.

title: Capital return
body: Capital return per share

title: Capital return
body: The capital return payed per share. The value will become the unit price of the transaction created.

title: Capital return
body: Annual meeting date

title: Capital return
body: The annual meeting date.

title: Capital return
body: Expiration date*

title: Capital return
body: The expiration date. The capital return is calculated based on the amount of security in the portfolio on the expiration date. This date will become the transaction date of the transaction created.

title: Capital return
body: Settlement date

title: Capital return
body: The settlement date of the capital return, e.g. when the capital return is actually paid to the portfolio.

title: Capital return
body: Transaction type*

title: Capital return
body: The transaction type for the transactions to be created (if recording capital returns, select "Capital return" or similar).

title: Capital return
body: A new corporate action is created with the OK button below the corporate action information. Remember to run the corporate action to your portfolio(s) in order to create appropriate transactions to your portfolios

title: Coupon payment
body: With the Coupon payment corporate action, the system automatically calculates a coupon related to a chosen security, and by running the coupon payment corporate action to the portfolios you can pay the coupon to multiple portfolios at once.

title: Define coupon information
body: In order for the coupon payment corporate action to work correctly, some information has to be defined for the security the coupon is calculated and paid for. Before creating the coupon payment corporate action, make sure that the security the coupon is payed for has the following bond information defined in the Extra info tab on the Security window:

title: Define coupon information
body: Define Issue date and Maturity date. This information is shown in the corporate action if defined for the security.

title: Define coupon information
body: Set the calendar and frequency. For fixed rate bonds, also define the first fixing date and fixing (i.e. the fixed annual coupon rate). For floating rate bonds, define the fixings individually at the bottom of the window (set the date from which the defined coupon rate is valid from, e.g. 1.1.2014 and 5,00 % would indicate that the coupon rate is 5,00 % from the beginning of 2014 onward).

title: Define coupon information
body: Define other relevant bond information.

title: Create coupon payment corporate action
body: After the coupon information is recorded for the security (bond) the coupon is paid for, the coupon payment can be recorded as a corporate action. Define the following information to the corporate action (a red star indicates a mandatory field).

title: Create coupon payment corporate action
body: Action type

title: Create coupon payment corporate action
body: The type of the corporate action (Coupon payment).

title: Create coupon payment corporate action
body: Security*

title: Create coupon payment corporate action
body: Security the coupon is payed for.

title: Create coupon payment corporate action
body: After the security the coupon is paid for is chosen, the rest of the fields will be filled in automatically, if the coupon information described above was recorded to the security information of the bond chosen.

title: Create coupon payment corporate action
body: Interest rate*

title: Create coupon payment corporate action
body: The coupon rate the coupon is calculated with. The coupon rate is calculated automatically from the coupon information saved for the security, based on the coupon calendar and the coupon rate and either the coupon frequency and first coupon date defined for fixed rate bonds or the individual coupons defined for floating rate notes. For example, for semi-annual coupon payments the coupon rate used for calculating the semi-annual coupon payment differs from the annual coupon rate defined for the security. The interest rate will become the unit price of the coupon payment transaction. The pre-calculated rate can also be modified manually.

title: Create coupon payment corporate action
body: Next coupon date*

title: Create coupon payment corporate action
body: The coupon date. The coupon date is automatically chosen to be the nearest coupon date based on the coupon frequency defined for the chosen security, or the previous coupon date based on the coupon frequency defined for the chosen security: for fixed rate bonds, the coupon date is set based on the coupon frequency and the first coupon date, and for floating rate bonds based on the coupon frequency and the date of the first individual coupon defined (until FA 3.0). The coupon date will become the transaction date of the coupon payment transaction. The pre-defined date can also be modified manually.

title: Create coupon payment corporate action
body: Payment date*

title: Create coupon payment corporate action
body: The payment date of the coupon, e.g. when the coupon is actually paid.

title: Create coupon payment corporate action
body: Transaction type*

title: Create coupon payment corporate action
body: The transaction type for the transactions created to the portfolios from the coupon payment corporate action.

title: Create coupon payment corporate action
body: The rest of the information in the window summarizes the bond information defined for the security the coupon payment is created for. This information is shown as background information for the calculation of the coupon payment. If there is no information visible, make sure your have defined them for the security you are paying the coupon to

title: Create coupon payment corporate action
body: First coupon date - the first coupon date defined in security's Bond info.

title: Create coupon payment corporate action
body: Issue date - the issue date of the bond defined in security's Basic info.

title: Create coupon payment corporate action
body: Maturity date - the maturity date of the bond defined in security's Basic info.

title: Create coupon payment corporate action
body: Accrual calendar - the coupon calendar of the bond defined in security's Bond info.

title: Create coupon payment corporate action
body: Coupon frequency - the coupon frequency of the bond defined in security's Bond info.

title: Create coupon payment corporate action
body: Coupon rate (annual) - the annual coupon rate of the bond defined in security's Bond info.

title: Create coupon payment corporate action
body: A new corporate action is created with the OK button below the corporate action information.

title: Run the coupon payment to selected portfolios
body: A created corporate action does not affect any portfolios by itself, but the corporate action has to be run to the affected portfolios in order to create the coupon payment transactions.

title: Run the coupon payment to selected portfolios
body: Choose the portfolio / portfolios you want to run the coupon payment to. By choosing all portfolios or a group of portfolios in the run, the coupon payment transaction will be calculated to all portfolios containing the security of the coupon payment.

title: Run the coupon payment to selected portfolios
body: Define the tax rate and tax type to be used in the transactions created (you can also define default tax rates in Preferences - Default tax rates to be used automatically).

title: Run the coupon payment to selected portfolios
body: Click Run & close to get a preview of the transactions to be created as a result of the run. Click Accept and run to create the shown transactions to the portfolios. Alternatively, you can schedule the corporate action to be run by the system on a later date by defining a date and time and clicking the Schedule & run button.

title: Dividend
body: The dividend corporate action can be mainly used as a tool for recording dividends to your portfolios.

title: Dividend
body: The dividend corporate action can be used as a tool to create transactions in other situations as well, for example when running an expiration of a bond. The dividend corporate action takes the amount for the transactions from the position of the chosen security in the portfolio, and uses the dividend per share defined in the corporate action as the unit price in calculating the trade amount of the created transaction.

title: Dividend
body: The dividend corporate action can be recorded to the system through the Corporate action window with the following information (a star indicates a mandatory field):

title: Dividend
body: Security*

title: Dividend
body: The security the dividend is paid for. The amount of this security in the portfolio will determine the amount of the dividend transaction created.

title: Dividend
body: Currency

title: Dividend
body: The currency the dividend is paid out in. By default the dividend currency is the security’s currency. When the currency of the dividend is set to other than the security’s currency, the dividend transaction is recorded to your portfolios so that the dividend is calculated in the dividend currency and converted appropriately to security currency with the defined exchange rate.

title: Dividend
body: Dividend per share

title: Dividend
body: The dividend paid per share. This value will become the unit price of the created transaction.

title: Dividend
body: Annual meeting date

title: Dividend
body: The annual meeting date.

title: Dividend
body: Dividend ex-date*

title: Dividend
body: The dividend ex-date. The dividend is calculated based on the amount of security in the portfolio on the morning of the dividend ex-date (i.e. the position after the previous day's transactions). This date will become the transaction date of the created transaction.

title: Dividend
body: Settlement date

title: Dividend
body: The settlement date of the dividend, i.e. when the dividend is actually paid to the portfolio. This date will become the settlement date of the created transaction.

title: Dividend
body: Transaction type*

title: Dividend
body: The transaction type for the transactions to be created (if recording dividends, select "Dividend" or similar).

title: Dividend
body: A new corporate action is created with the OK button below the corporate action information. Remember to run the corporate action to your portfolio(s) in order to create appropriate transactions to your portfolios.

title: Dividend as shares
body: The dividend as shares corporate action can be used as a tool for recording dividends as shares to your portfolios.

title: Dividend as shares
body: Dividend as shares is handled so that the dividend paid per security is converted into dividend securities based on the purchase price of the dividend security. If the amount of the dividend security received is not a whole number after the conversion, the remainder is paid as a regular dividend.

title: Dividend as shares
body: For example, there are 100 securities A in a portfolio, and a dividend of 0,50 € is paid per share A. The value of the dividend is thereafter 100 * 0,50 € = 50 €. If the dividend is paid as shares of security B, and the unit purchase price of B is 3 €, 16 B shares are paid as dividend as shares, and 16 * 3 € = 48 € (since 50 / 3 =16,67). The dividend paid as shares is not a whole number of shares, and the rest of the dividend, 50 € - 48 € = 2 €, is paid as regular dividend.

title: Dividend as shares
body: The dividend as shares corporate action can be recorded to the system through the Corporate action window with the following information (a star indicates a mandatory field):

title: Dividend as shares
body: Security*

title: Dividend as shares
body: The security the dividend is paid for. The amount of this security in the portfolio will determine the amount of the dividend transaction created.

title: Dividend as shares
body: Dividend security

title: Dividend as shares
body: The security that is paid as the dividend.

title: Dividend as shares
body: Unit price per share*

title: Dividend as shares
body: The unit price per share of the dividend security (the unit price of the security paid as the dividend).

title: Dividend as shares
body: Dividend per share*

title: Dividend as shares
body: The dividend paid per share.

title: Dividend as shares
body: Annual meeting date

title: Dividend as shares
body: The annual meeting date.

title: Dividend as shares
body: Dividend ex-date*

title: Dividend as shares
body: The dividend ex-date. The dividend is calculated based on the amount of security in the portfolio on the dividend ex-date. This date will become the purchase date of the security received as the dividend and the transaction date of the transactions created.

title: Dividend as shares
body: Settlement date

title: Dividend as shares
body: The settlement date of the dividend, i.e. when the dividend is actually paid to the portfolio.

title: Dividend as shares
body: Transaction type*

title: Dividend as shares
body: The transaction type for the dividend transactions ("Dividend" or similar).

title: Dividend as shares
body: Transaction type 2*

title: Dividend as shares
body: The transaction type for the transactions related to the new securities acquired as the dividend ("Dividend as shares" or similar).

title: Dividend as shares
body: A new corporate action is created with the OK button below the corporate action information. Remember to run the corporate action to your portfolio(s) in order to create appropriate transactions for your portfolios.

title: Exchange
body: The exchange corporate action can be used as a tool for recording exchanges, i.e. in situations where one security is exchanged into one or more other securities.

title: Exchange
body: In addition to directly exchanging one security to another, the exchange corporate action supports dividing the purchase values of the original security to the new securities received in the exchange, as well as exchanging securities with different currencies. The exchange corporate action can be used for example for recording changes of security, spin-offs, redemption shares and convertible bonds. The exchange corporate action creates one transaction per open purchase lots for each new security added, calculates the amount for the transactions from the ratio and the position of the chosen security in the portfolio, and uses the percentage share of the original purchase value of the position as the trade amount of the created transaction.

title: Exchange
body: The exchange corporate action can be recorded to the system through the Corporate action window with the following information (a star indicates a mandatory field):

title: Exchange
body: Removed security*

title: Exchange
body: The security that is exchanged to another security (i.e. choose the security that is removed from the portfolio and exchanged into some other security).

title: Exchange
body: Exchange date*

title: Exchange
body: The date of the exchange. The exchange date will become the transaction date of the transaction created.

title: Exchange
body: Transaction type*

title: Exchange
body: he transaction type for the transactions to be created (if recording exchanges, select "Exchange" or similar).

title: Exchange
body: To the fields below, define the security / securities the removed security is exchanged to (add a new row for each new security you receive from the exchange). New securities can be added with the + button, and exchange information can be defined in the fields available per security added:

title: Exchange
body: New security*

title: Exchange
body: The security that is received in the exchange.

title: Exchange
body: Exchange ratio*

title: Exchange
body: The exchange ratio (for example 1:2). The ratio defines how many new securities are received with one removed security.

title: Exchange
body: Fx rate*

title: Exchange
body: The exchange rate used, if the currency of the removed security is different from the currency of the new security. By default, the exchange rate it 1 (exchanged securities are of the same currency).

title: Exchange
body: Share (%)*

title: Exchange
body: The percent of the purchase value of the original security will be transferred as the purchase value of the new security. By default, the share is 100 % (the whole purchase value of removed security is transferred to the new security, usually the case when exchanging one security to another).

title: Exchange
body: However, if a security is exchange into two securities (for example due to a spin-off) the purchase value of the removed security might be divided unevenly to the new securities: the division of the original purchase value of the removed security is defined to this field as a percentage.

title: Exchange
body: The exchange corporate action does not support changing a security to itself. If you need to exchange a security to itself, for example when recording a spin-off (a security spins off to itself and a new security), the removed security has to first be exchanged to a "temporary security" (create one to the system) and the temporary security can then be exchanged back to the original security with a new exchange corporate action.

title: Exchange
body: A new corporate action is created with the OK button below the corporate action information. Remember to run the corporate action to your portfolio(s) in order to create appropriate transactions to your portfolios.

title: Issue
body: The issue corporate action can be used as a tool for recording issues, i.e. situations when new securities are issued based on the ownership of another security.

title: Issue
body: The issue corporate action can be used in any kinds of issues, for example when recording subscription rights issues, i.e. when an owner of a security gets subscription rights. The issue corporate action creates as many transactions as there are open purchase lots in the position the issue is based on, and keeps track of the original purchase dates.

title: Issue
body: The issue corporate action can be recorded to the system through the Corporate action window with the following information (a star indicates a mandatory field):

title: Issue
body: Security*

title: Issue
body: The security the issue is based on (for example the security issuing the subscription rights). The amount of this security in the portfolio together with the ratio will determine the amount of the transaction created.

title: Issue
body: Issued security*

title: Issue
body: The issued security (the security received from the issue).

title: Issue
body: Issue date*

title: Issue
body: The date of the issue. The issue date will become the transaction date of the transaction created.

title: Issue
body: Price / unit

title: Issue
body: The unit price of the issued security (or leave as 0 if the issue is of no charge). The unite price will become the unit price of the transaction created.

title: Issue
body: Issue ratio

title: Issue
body: The issue ratio (for example 1:2). The ratio determines how many new securities are received per one original security (for example, if with one security you will receive two subscription rights, ratio would be 1:2).

title: Issue
body: Transaction type*

title: Issue
body: The transaction type for the transactions to be created (if recording subscription rights issues, select "Subscription rights issue" or similar).

title: Issue
body: A new corporate action is created with the OK button below the corporate action information. Remember to run the corporate action to your portfolio(s) in order to create appropriate transactions to your portfolios.

title: Split
body: The split corporate action can be used as a tool for recording splits and bonus issues.

title: Split
body: When running a split corporate action to your portfolio, the created transaction will have no other information as the security, transaction type, date and ratio (i.e. 0 in amount, unit price, trade amount, etc.) - this information alone will be enough to take the split into account in the reports.

title: Split
body: The split corporate action can be recorded to the system through the Corporate action window with the following information (a star indicates a mandatory field):

title: Split
body: Security*

title: Split
body: The security that splits.

title: Split
body: Split date*

title: Split
body: The date of the split. The split is calculated based on the amount of security in the portfolio on the split date. This date will become the transaction date of the transaction created.

title: Split
body: Split ratio

title: Split
body: The ratio of the split (for example 1:2). The ratio defined tells the ratio between the amount of securities before and after the split (thus, with ratio 1:2, one security before the split would become two securities after the split, and the amount of the securities would double).

title: Split
body: Transaction type*

title: Split
body: The transaction type for the transactions to be created (if recording splits, select "Split" or similar).

title: Split
body: A new corporate action is created with the OK button below the corporate action information. Remember to run the corporate action to your portfolio(s) in order to create appropriate transactions to your portfolios.

title: Subscription
body: The subscription corporate action can be used as a tool for recording subscriptions, i.e. situations when new securities are subscribed based on the ownership of another security.

title: Subscription
body: The subscription corporate action can be used in any kinds of subscriptions, for example for recording subscriptions of a security based on the ownership of subscription rights to that security. The subscription corporate action creates one transaction per portfolio, calculates the amount for the transactions from the ratio and the position of the chosen security in the portfolio, and uses the unit price defined in the corporate action as the unit price in calculating the trade amount of the created transaction.

title: Subscription
body: The subscription corporate action can be recorded to the system through the Corporate action window with the following information (a star indicates a mandatory field):

title: Subscription
body: Security*

title: Subscription
body: The security the subscription is based on (for example the subscription right security). The amount of this security in the portfolio together with the ratio will determine the amount of the transaction created.

title: Subscription
body: Issued security*

title: Subscription
body: The subscribed security (the security received from the subscription).

title: Subscription
body: Issue date*

title: Subscription
body: The date of the subscription. The subscription date will become the transaction date of the transaction created.

title: Subscription
body: Unit price

title: Subscription
body: The unit price of the subscription. The unite price will become the unit price of the transaction created.

title: Subscription
body: Issue ratio

title: Subscription
body: The subscription ratio (for example 1:2). The ratio determines how many new securities are received with one original security (for example, if with one subscription right you will receive two original securities, ratio would be 1:2).

title: Subscription
body: Transaction type*

title: Subscription
body: The transaction type for the transactions to be created (if recording subscriptions, select "Subscription" or similar).

title: Subscription
body: A new corporate action is created with the OK button below the corporate action information. Remember to run the corporate action to your portfolio(s) in order to create appropriate transactions to your portfolios.

title: Record and run corporate actions to client portfolios
body: To run corporate actions, you can choose a workflow that suits you:

title: Record and run corporate actions to client portfolios
body: To create corporate actions for specific securities and run them per portfolio, contact, or portfolio group, follow the steps described here.

title: Record and run corporate actions to client portfolios
body: To create, schedule, and run coupon payments and bond expirations for all securities in the system, see Mass-generate coupons and expirations.

title: Step 1 - Create and define a corporate action
body: Create and define a corporate action per security, specifying the corporate action type and details, such as date, transaction type, prices per share, ratios, and so on:

title: Step 1 - Create and define a corporate action
body: Create a corporate action. You can choose from the following options:

title: Step 1 - Create and define a corporate action
body: To create a corporate action that affects a single customer or portfolio, click Menu and New - New corporate action. The customer or portfolio you have selected in the Overview is suggested as the default target.

title: Step 1 - Create and define a corporate action
body: To create a corporate action that affects multiple portfolios, click New corporate action in the Corporate action view.

title: Step 1 - Create and define a corporate action
body: Choose the corporate action type (see Corporate action types).

title: Step 1 - Create and define a corporate action
body: Fill in the fields in the upper part of the Corporate action run window for the selected corporate action type. For field descriptions for each corporate action type, see Corporate action types. Close the window or proceed to the next step.

title: Step 1 - Create and define a corporate action
body: Creating a corporate action does not yet affect any portfolios, because the corporate action has to be run to the selected portfolios first.

title: Step 2 - Run a corporate action
body: Create a corporate action run per portfolio or portfolio group, specifying tax information, and exchange rates. You can run the corporate action now or schedule it for a future date.

title: Step 2 - Run a corporate action
body: To run or schedule the corporate action, do the following:

title: Step 2 - Run a corporate action
body: In the Corporate action view, click New corporate action. To run a previously defined corporate action, search for it in the Corporate action view and click New run.

title: Step 2 - Run a corporate action
body: Select the portfolios to include in the corporate action run and fill in the taxation information and exchange rates. Fill in the taxation information and exchange rates. For descriptions of the taxation and exchange rate fields, see Corporate action window in FA Back reference.

title: Step 2 - Run a corporate action
body: Choose if you want to schedule the corporate action for later or run it now:

title: Step 2 - Run a corporate action
body: To schedule the corporate action for later, specify the date and time, and click Schedule & close. For a scheduled corporate action, the process is complete.

title: Step 2 - Run a corporate action
body: To run the corporate action now, click Run & close and proceed to the next step.

title: Step 2 - Run a corporate action
body: Review the transactions suggested by the system in the Transactions window. You can uncheck each transaction to prevent it from being created. If needed, click Change parameters to return to the previous window and edit the run settings.

title: Step 2 - Run a corporate action
body: Click Accept and run to create the selected transactions.

title: Step 2 - Run a corporate action
body: The system then creates transactions in the selected portfolios using the corporate action security position on the morning of the corporate action (position after the previous day) and the information you defined.

title: Delete runs and corporate actions
body: You can delete the run and the transactions created by it by doing the following:

title: Delete runs and corporate actions
body: In the Corporate action view, click on the corporate action and double-click the run. You can review the transactions created by the run by clicking Show transactions.

title: Delete runs and corporate actions
body: Click Delete. The transactions created to the portfolios by the run are deleted.

title: Delete runs and corporate actions
body: If you want to delete the corporate action itself or, for example, you imported a corporate action by mistake, do the following:

title: Delete runs and corporate actions
body: Delete all runs for the corporate action.

title: Delete runs and corporate actions
body: Double-click the corporate action and click Delete.

title: Related links
body: Corporate action window in FA Back reference

title: Handle rights issues
body: Rights issue consists of the following phases:

title: Handle rights issues
body: Registration of Subscription Rights

title: Handle rights issues
body: Exercise Subscription Rights by subscribing for shares (either company shares directly or Interim Shares)

title: Handle rights issues
body: If Interim Shares are used, exchange the interim shares for company shares

title: Handle rights issues
body: This document details the different ways the rights issues can be handled in FA platform using corporate action functionalities.

title: Handle rights issues
body: The rights issues can be handled differently depending on taxation. The key difference is whether the subscription rights are considered having some purchase value. For example, in some jurisdictions private person taxation requires subscription rights not having purchase price while company taxation requires the purchase price.

title: Handle rights issues
body: The example case used here is Enedo Plc's Rights Issue in 2021. In that rights issue the key details were the following:

title: Handle rights issues
body: Shareholders will receive three subscription rights for every one share owned (1:3 ratio). The ex-rights date is 12 March.

title: Handle rights issues
body: Subscription rights holders are entitled to subscribe one offer share for one subscription right (1:1 ratio) during the subscription period, from 18 March to 1 April.

title: Handle rights issues
body: Interim shares represent offer shares until 9 April, when the interim shares are exchanged for company shares.

title: Handle rights issues
body: Before proceeding, make sure you have created the securities (company share, subscription right and interim share (if used)) in the system. In the example case used here they would be ENEDO FH (the regular company share of type Equity), ENEDOU01 FH (the subscription right of type Entitlements) and ENEDON01 FH (the interim share of type Equity).

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: Registration of subscription rights

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: This step can be done as either Issue or Exchange type corporate action, depending on how you want to handle purchase values of the subscription rights.

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: If you don't want to have purchase value on on the subscription rights, or you want to valuate the subscription rights with their calculated value, use corporate action of type Issue with the following details:

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: Security: The security bearing subscription rights (for example, ENEDO FH)

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: Issued security: The Subscription Right (for example, ENEDOU01 FH)

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: Issue date: Ex-rights date (for example, 12 March)

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: Price/unit: Calculated price of the subscription right, or 0 if you don't want to have purchase value on the subscription rights. Note that the given purchase value reduces the purchase value of the original purchase lot of the share.

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: Subscription ratio: The ratio with which you will receive subscription rights for every share you own (e.g. 1:3)

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: Transaction type: Subscription rights issue (C), SRIC, if you had purchase value, or Subscription rights issue, SRI, if you didn't have purchase value

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: If you want to valuate the subscription rights as percentage of original purchase lot's purchase price, use corporate action of type Exchange with the following details:

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: Removed security: The security bearing subscription rights (for example, ENEDO FH)

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: Exchange date: Ex-rights date (for example, 12 March)

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: Transaction type: Subscription rights issue (C), SRIC

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: New security: The Subscription Right (for example, ENEDOU01 FH)

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: New security Exchange ratio: The ratio with which you will receive subscription rights for every share you own (e.g. 1:3)

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: New security Share: The percentage of the original purchase lot's purchase price you want to use for the purchase price of the subscription right. For example, if you have a purchase lot with purchase value of 2000 EUR and input 10 as the percentage, the subscription rights assigned to that purchase lot get the total purchase value of 200 EUR and the purchase value of the original lot is reduced to 1800 EUR.

title: Subscribe for shares
body: Subscribe for shares

title: Subscribe for shares
body: Create a new corporate action of type Subscription with the following details:

title: Subscribe for shares
body: Security: The Subscription Right (for example, ENEDOU01 FH)

title: Subscribe for shares
body: Issued security: The Interim Share (for example, ENEDON01 FH), or the company share, if no interim shares are used

title: Subscribe for shares
body: Subscription/Payment date: Self explanatory (for example, 1 April)

title: Subscribe for shares
body: Subscription price: Self explanatory (for example, 0.2)

title: Subscribe for shares
body: Subscription ratio: The ratio with which you will receive shares for every subscription right (for example, 1:1)

title: Subscribe for shares
body: Transaction type: Exercise subscription right (C),SUBSC or Exercise subscription right, SUBS, depending on whether you selected SRIC or SRI in the earlier step

title: Exchange interim shares
body: Exchange interim shares

title: Exchange interim shares
body: This step is only needed if the interim shares are used. If the subscription rights were exchanged directly for the company shares, you can skip this step.

title: Exchange interim shares
body: Create a new corporate action of type Subscription with the following details:

title: Exchange interim shares
body: Security: The Interim Share (for example, ENEDON01 FH)

title: Exchange interim shares
body: Issued security: The company share (for example, ENEDO FH)

title: Exchange interim shares
body: Subscription/Payment date: The date on which the interim shares are exchanged for the company shares (for example, 9 April)

title: Exchange interim shares
body: Subscription price: 0

title: Exchange interim shares
body: Subscription ratio: 1:1

title: Exchange interim shares
body: Transaction type: Exchange (issue), EXCHISS

title: Exchange interim shares
body: The Exchange (issue) transaction type is used instead of Exchange to get the purchase value add up correctly

title: Securities
body: The FA Platform allows you to record operations with different kinds of securities such as equities, bonds, or fund units as well as derivatives and FX contracts. To work with bonds, see Bonds. To work with complex securities like derivatives and FX contracts in FA, see Derivatives and FX contracts. For a list of security types in FA, see Standard security types.

title: Securities
body: You can create new securities or update existing ones in the Security window. See Security window in FA Back reference for details on adding information for securities. You can also search for and view securities saved in the system in the Securities view (see Securities view in FA Back reference).

title: Securities
body: You can also import securities in files or from a market data provider. To fetch security information from market data providers, see Get security data and Get extended security data. For importing securities in files, see File formats for importing securities and security prices in FA Back reference.

title: Securities
body: Security market prices can also be entered manually, fetched from a market data provider, or imported in files (see Manage market prices).

title: Securities
body: You can track and analyze security indicators such as duration, modified duration, convexity, and YTM for securities. For this, you need to define the key figures. See ??? for more information.

title: Securities
body: To read about security configurations in the system, see Security preferences.

title: Loans as bonds
body: Loans are used to borrow money for investment purposes. A loan with regular interest payments is set up in FA Back as a bond. You can track accrued interest, calculate interest payments, and handle loan repayment.

title: Create a loan security
body: Create a loan security

title: Create a loan security
body: To create a loan security:

title: Create a loan security
body: Choose New → New security in the top menu. The Security window opens.

title: Create a loan security
body: Fill in the fields:

title: Create a loan security
body: Basic info tab:

title: Create a loan security
body: Code, Name – Create a code and name that contain information about the loan dates and currency.

title: Create a loan security
body: Security type – "Debt instruments (BOND)".

title: Create a loan security
body: Sub type – "DY: Money Market Instruments".

title: Create a loan security
body: Multipliers – "100".

title: Create a loan security
body: Issuer – Choose the contact of the counterparty.

title: Create a loan security
body: Extra info tab:

title: Create a loan security
body: Issue date – Loan start date.

title: Create a loan security
body: Issue price – "1".

title: Create a loan security
body: Maturity date – Loan end date.

title: Create a loan security
body: Maturity price – "1".

title: Create a loan security
body: Calendar (day count convention) – The agreed day counting convention.

title: Create a loan security
body: Frequency – "Once".

title: Create a loan security
body: Fixings for floating rate note – Start date and agreed loan rate.

title: Create a loan security
body: You can have multiple coupon periods both with a fixed or floating rate. The security configuration in the Extra info tab is the same as for a bond.

title: Add a loan to a portfolio
body: Add a loan to a portfolio

title: Add a loan to a portfolio
body: To add a loan to a portfolio, use a sell transaction. Enter an ID from another system or your counterparty in the Reference field and choose the counterparty in the Counterparty field.

title: Create interest payments and expirations
body: Create interest payments and expirations

title: Create interest payments and expirations
body: Interest payments and maturity processing are handled in the same way as for bonds. To generate coupon payments and expirations, create and run a corporate action. An important note: use the "Expire short position (EXPSH)" transaction type.

title: Create interest payments and expirations
body: To create and run a corporate action, use one of the tools that suits you best:

title: Create interest payments and expirations
body: For a coupon payment on one bond, follow the steps in Record and run corporate actions to client portfolios.

title: Create interest payments and expirations
body: For coupon payments on multiple bonds, import corporate actions in a file (see File format for importing corporate actions) and run them from the Corporate actions view in FA Back (see Record and run corporate actions to client portfolios).

title: Create interest payments and expirations
body: For coupon payments and expirations on all bonds in the system, use the functionality described in Mass-generate coupons and expirations.

title: Reconciliation
body: The reconciliation feature allows you to:

title: Reconciliation
body: Compare account balances and position data from an external source (for example, your custodian or a bank) with the data in the FA system to identify the mismatches. You can carry out reconciliation in FA Operations (recommended) or in FA Back. FA Operations is a newer app that gradually replaces FA Back for operations-related functionality.

title: Reconciliation
body: For reconciliation instructions in FA Operations, see Reconciliation. For reconciliation instructions in FA Back, see Create a reconciliation file and Reconcile a portfolio.

title: Reconciliation
body: Export positions from FA to reconcile or update data in another FA instance, or in a third-party system. For instructions, see Export positions from FA.

title: Reconciliation flow in the FA system
body: The reconciliation flow in the FA system includes the following stages:

title: Reconciliation flow in the FA system
body: Obtain position or cash balance data from the bank or custodian.

title: Reconciliation flow in the FA system
body: Upload the file or transfer it to the FA system automatically. For uploading the data in FA Operations, see Set up data sources. For uploading the data from M2Wealth and reconciling it in FA Back, see M2 Wealth.

title: Reconciliation flow in the FA system
body: View the reconciliation result in the FA system. See Reconciliation in FA Operations documentation if you use FA Operations app, or Reconcile a portfolio in FA User guide if you use FA Back.

title: Reconciliation flow in the FA system
body: Fix mismatches by correcting transaction information.

title: Related links
body: M2 Wealth in FA User guide

title: Related links
body: Reconciliation and FA Operations in FA Product Description

title: Related links
body: FA Operations

title: Create a reconciliation file
body: There are two supported formats of reconciliation files in FA:

title: Create a reconciliation file
body: MT535 – If your custodian sends the data in the MT535 format, you can skip the reconciliation file creation and move on to performing the actual reconciliation (see the instruction in Reconcile a portfolio).

title: Create a reconciliation file
body: FA reconciliation file – If your custodian provides the reconciliation data in any other format than MT535, you need to transform the data into the standard FA format first.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: The reconciliation file in FA format is a CSV file with the following characteristics:

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: The default field separator is a semicolon. You can configure FA to accept files with a different separator. The separator must be only one character.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: The record separator must be \r\n (CRLF).
