title: FA reconciliation file format
body: Numbers must use "." (point) as a decimal separator and no thousands separator.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: If the file contains non-standard characters, the encoding must be ISO-8859-1.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: File name can be any.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: FA reconciliation file contains the following fields (the field names must be used as headers in the first row of the file):

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: portfolio: Portfolio ID (as seen in the Portfolio window in FA Back).

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: date: Date in the yyyy-MM-dd format (having two or more different dates in the file results in an error task and the file isn't processed).

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: amount: Position amount or account balance.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: security: Any of securityCode / isin / tradeCode / updateCode1 / updateCode2 / updateCode3 is supported (either this or account is mandatory).

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: account: Account number.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: currency: Optional. It’s recommended to include currency in the reconciliation file - the system uses this information to match positions and cash accounts in different currencies, in case they have the same ID or account number.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: Download the CSV file example:

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: fa_example_reconciliation_file.csv

title: Configure field separator for reconciliation files
body: By default, the reconciliation files must use a semicolon as a field separator. To use some other character, you need to specify it in FA Back settings:

title: Configure field separator for reconciliation files
body: Go to Tools → Administer → Data aggregation and open the Reconciliation tab.

title: Configure field separator for reconciliation files
body: Set the delimiter in the Delimiter field and click Close.

title: Reconcile a portfolio
body: This page describes how to reconcile data in FA Back. We recommend using FA Operations application for reconciliation. For instructions, see FA Operations.

title: Reconcile a portfolio
body: To reconcile position or cash balance data from an external source in FA Back, upload the file with external data, view the reconciliation results in the Tasks view, and correct the mismatches.

title: Upload the reconciliation file and view the reconciliation result
body: Upload the reconciliation file and view the reconciliation result

title: Upload the reconciliation file and view the reconciliation result
body: Upload the file with the data from your custodian:

title: Upload the reconciliation file and view the reconciliation result
body: Open Tools → Import file → Reconciliation material and select the file from your computer. Select the format (FA format or MT535) and choose if you want to perform the reconciliation based on the transaction date or settlement date of transactions.

title: Upload the reconciliation file and view the reconciliation result
body: View the results in the Tasks view, Reconciliation dashboard. If there are any mismatches, open the task to see details.

title: Upload the reconciliation file and view the reconciliation result
body: (Optional) View the portfolios with position reconciliation mismatches in the "Position reconciliation errors" dynamic portfolio group. You can find this group, for example, in the Overview.

title: Correct portfolio positions
body: You can fix the reconciliation errors while having the window with reconciliation results open at the same time:

title: Correct portfolio positions
body: Open the Reconciliation - Errors in the Portfolios view. Portfolios with errors have the "Reconciliation-Errors" tag and are listed in the view.

title: Correct portfolio positions
body: Choose the portfolio and click Reconcile → Positions at the bottom. The Reconcile portfolio window opens.

title: Correct portfolio positions
body: Choose the reconciliation date and click Reconcile. You will see the list of mismatching portfolio positions.

title: Correct portfolio positions
body: While having the window open, correct portfolio positions in FA Back views if needed or use the Ignore to ignore an item.

title: Correct portfolio positions
body: Click Reconcile to re-run the reconciliation against updated content (and save ignored items), and show the new result.

title: Skip extra positions in FA system
body: By default, position reconciliation shows a mismatch if it finds extra positions that are present in FA Back but missing in your custodian's reconciliation file. You can change this behavior by excluding a portfolio or a security from reconciliation:

title: Skip extra positions in FA system
body: Ignore all extra positions in the specified portfolio – for example, if the portfolio contains positions from multiple custodians, and the reconciliation is done custodian-by-custodian. To set up this option, open the Portfolio window, Basic info tab and enable "Reconciliation: Ignore extra positions in FA".

title: Skip extra positions in FA system
body: Ignore extra positions in a certain security in all portfolios – for example, if the reconciled portfolios include unlisted assets that are missing from the reconciliation file provided by your custodian. To set up this option, open the Security window, Basic info tab and enable "Reconciliation: Ignore extra positions in FA".

title: Questions about portfolio reconciliation
body: I have my cash balance in the correct format, but the system says that the file amount is 0. How can I fix this?

title: Questions about portfolio reconciliation
body: Check out the decimal separator - it needs to be a dot (“.”).

title: Questions about portfolio reconciliation
body: My reconciliation gives POS_NFOUND errors, even if the portfolio has these positions. How can I fix this?

title: Questions about portfolio reconciliation
body: Check out the portfolio code: it can't have a comma inside the code.

title: Transactions
body: Transactions are used to handle and register operations with securities and cash, such as buying and selling assets, or depositing cash. Portfolio positions and cash amounts are calculated based on transactions. Once a transaction is accepted, portfolio positions and cash amounts are recalculated. You can create transactions directly (see Add transactions) or generate them based on trade orders (see Trade order execution). If you use FA accounting, bookkeeping entries are created based on transactions.

title: Transactions
body: The FA Platform has a set of transaction types for cash and security transactions (see Transaction types for cash transactions and Transaction types for security transactions). The transaction types are specific to security types (for example: coupon payments are specific to debt instruments). Some transaction types are shared between several security types (for example: buying and selling are available for several security types).

title: Transactions
body: Each transaction type has certain effects on the portfolio. For example, the cash effect of a buy transaction is to reduce the cash balance of the transaction account, and the cash effect of a sell transaction is to add to the cash balance of the transaction account. For more information about transaction effects, see Preference - Transactions in FA Back reference.

title: Transactions
body: A transaction includes costs, fees, and taxes which you specify either as a percentage or an amount (see Fees and Portfolios view in FA Back reference). The effects defined for the transaction type determine if the costs, fees, and taxes are added to the transaction amount or subtracted from it. You can also extract the costs and taxes into separate transactions, for example, to keep track of costs in a separate portfolio (see Extract costs and taxes as separate transactions).

title: Transactions
body: You can also import transactions in files (see File formats for importing transactions and trade orders in FA Back reference).

title: Transaction types
body: In the FA Platform, each security type has a set of transaction types you can use. For a list of transaction types available by default, see Transaction types for security transactions and Transaction types for cash transactions.

title: Transaction types
body: Modifying transaction types is not recommended. Transaction types are defined to work in specific scenarios and changes can cause, for example, incorrect performance calculations. Instead of editing the transaction types, you can rename them or add new ones.

title: Transaction types
body: If you want to modify the name of an existing transaction type, you can use the Translate button in Transaction types (Preference, Transactions section). You should not modify the transaction type name directly.

title: Add a transaction type
body: You can add a new transaction type if the standard types do not include a suitable type for your needs. Use a similar existing type as an example. If you need to create a transaction type from scratch, contact FA support to ensure that no problems occur, for example, with profit calculations.

title: Add a transaction type
body: To add a new transaction type, do the following:

title: Add a transaction type
body: Open Transaction types (Preference, Transactions section) and click Add transaction type.

title: Add a transaction type
body: Fill in the fields and make sure all effects are correct (see Preference - Transactions in FA Back reference).

title: Add a transaction type
body: Click Save.

title: Questions about transaction types
body: I get several different cost and profit transactions from my custody. I want to record all of them in FA. Can I add a transaction type for this?

title: Questions about transaction types
body: Yes, you can add a new transaction type for this. Copy the transaction type effects from a similar standard transaction type and link the new transaction type to the necessary security types.

title: Add transactions
body: You can create transactions from scratch or based on a portfolio position, for example, to sell or buy a security already in your portfolio. Creating transactions from portfolio positions is useful for coupons, dividends, and sell-all situations. You can also create transactions based on a position in multiple portfolios for partial redemptions or security switches.

title: Add a transaction from scratch
body: To create a transaction from scratch, do the following:

title: Add a transaction from scratch
body: In the Overview, select the portfolio in which you want to add a transaction. If you select the portfolio first, the transaction is directly linked to the correct portfolio.

title: Add a transaction from scratch
body: Click New transaction in the New menu (top left) and select a security type.

title: Add a transaction from scratch
body: Fill in the fields in the Transaction window. For descriptions of the fields, see Transaction window in FA Back reference.

title: Add a transaction from scratch
body: Save the transaction.

title: Add a position-based transaction in a selected portfolio
body: To create a new transaction based on the position in the selected portfolio, do the following:

title: Add a position-based transaction in a selected portfolio
body: In the Overview, right-click the position row and select New.

title: Add a position-based transaction in a selected portfolio
body: Select Transaction with position’s security and amount where portfolio, security and amount are pre-filled based on the selected position, and transaction date is set to be the current date, or Transaction with position’s security, amount and trade amount where portfolio, security, amount, unit price, costs/taxes and trade amount are pre-filled based on the selected position, and transaction date is set to be the current date.

title: Add a position-based transaction in a selected portfolio
body: Fill in the fields. For descriptions of the fields, see Transaction window in FA Back reference.

title: Add a position-based transaction in a selected portfolio
body: Save the transaction.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: You can create transactions based on a position in multiple portfolios, for example, to do partial redemptions or switches from one security to another using the reinvest option.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: To create transactions based on the position in multiple portfolios, do the following:

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: In the Positions view, search for a position to use as a starting point.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: Click Create transactions and fill in the fields in the Generate transactions from positions window:

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: Create: The type of object to create. Select "Transactions".

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: Transaction type: The transaction type to use. The list of available types depends on the selected security.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: Amount: The amount as percentage of the original position size.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: Unit price: The unit price to use in the transactions. Enter a question mark to have the system automatically fill in the latest available price.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: Transaction date: The date when the transactions take effect.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: Settlement date: The settlement date of the transactions.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: Tags: The tags for the transactions.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: If the selected transaction type has a positive cash effect, reinvest by clicking Add security and filling in the fields, including the security to reinvest in. You can reinvest into multiple securities.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: Click Preview transactions to check the transactions to be created. You can uncheck transactions you do not want the system to create.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: Click Confirm.

title: Manage documents
body: FA allows you to store documents as files uploaded to the system and as links. You can manage and search for documents on the level of individual contacts, portfolios, securities, transactions, and trade orders or administer documents on the system level.

title: Search documents
body: You can search for documents in the Documents tab of the corresponding window for a contact, portfolio, security, transaction, or trade order. This search is available when you open a customer in the Customers view or select a contact or portfolio in the Overview. You can also search all documents stored in the system in the Administration view (see Administer documents in the system). The document search lists the document name and file type, the date and time the document was last modified, the modifier's username, and document tags.

title: Search documents
body: You can search for documents by name, date, time, modifier, and tags. The tag component allows you to search for documents with predefined document tags or dynamic document tags (the contact or portfolio ID, security code, or transaction/trade order external ID added dynamically to each document depending on which item it belongs to).

title: Search documents
body: To see documents in sub-folders in the search, enable the checkbox next to the icon in the top right. For example, you can see portfolio and transaction documents when viewing a contact. If a document folder has separate sub-folders, you can select them in a drop-down menu.

title: Upload documents
body: The following security measures ensure users cannot upload harmful documents into the system:

title: Upload documents
body: Allowed file types. The supported file types are: PDF, DOC, DOCX, ODT, XLS, XLSX, PPT, PPTX, ODP, ODS, TXT, CSV, XML, PNG, JPG, RTF, and MP3.

title: Upload documents
body: Maximum document size. To define the maximum file size users can upload, see Document management in FA Back reference (available from FA 3.5 onward). For example, if a typical file size is 10 MB, you can reject files larger than 25 MB.

title: Upload documents
body: Limit document upload frequency. To control how many documents a user can upload and how frequently (for example, a user can upload 1 new document every 10 seconds), see Document management in FA Back reference (available from FA 3.5 onward). If the system detects suspiciously frequent document uploads from a single user, the user is prohibited from uploading documents for some time.

title: Upload documents
body: Virus scanning. The system can scan all uploaded documents for viruses for additional security. If the system detects a virus, the document upload is prevented. By default, virus scanning is disabled. Contact FA if you want to enable virus scanning (available from FA 3.5 onward).

title: Upload documents
body: To add documents, do the following:

title: Upload documents
body: Select and open the component where you want to add documents (contact, portfolio, security, transaction, or trade order).

title: Upload documents
body: In the Documents tab, click Upload file.

title: Upload documents
body: Select the documents to upload from your computer.

title: Modify documents
body: You can right-click a document and download, modify, or delete it.

title: Modify documents
body: To modify a document, do the following:

title: Modify documents
body: Right-click the document and select Modify document.

title: Modify documents
body: Modify the document information in the available fields:

title: Modify documents
body: Rename: New document name.

title: Modify documents
body: Document path: The location of the document. Documents are stored under the main folders "Contacts", "Portfolios", and "Securities" and identified with the database ID of the contact, portfolio, or security. Transaction and trade order documents are stored in sub-folders within each portfolio folder, identified with the database ID of the transaction/trade order.

title: Modify documents
body: You can't edit the document path directly, but you can move the document into or out of a sub-folder. For example, you can rename a document "Contracts/NewContract.pdf" to place it into a sub-folder called "Contracts". To move the document back into the parent folder from "Contracts", you can rename the document "../NewContract.pdf". You can't delete sub-folders.

title: Modify documents
body: Document tags: Tags to apply to the document (see Preference - Tags in FA Back reference).

title: Modify documents
body: Click Save.

title: Link external documents
body: In addition to uploading documents into FA, you can upload links to documents stored online or in your internal document library. To link documents outside the FA system, ensure you have the appropriate permissions to view and manage them.

title: Link external documents
body: Linked documents are listed in document searches the same way as documents in the system. Linked documents have the icon and the extension ".link". To modify the link to a document, delete the linked document and upload the link again.

title: Link external documents
body: To upload a linked document, do the following:

title: Link external documents
body: Select and open the component where you want to add documents (contact, portfolio, security, transaction, or trade order).

title: Link external documents
body: In the Documents tab, click Upload link.

title: Link external documents
body: Fill in the fields:

title: Link external documents
body: Document name: The name shown in document listings.

title: Link external documents
body: Link to document: The URL address of the document. The link can for example point to a document stored online or to a document stored in your internal document library.

title: Link external documents
body: Click Save.

title: Administer documents in the system
body: In the Administration view, Documents tab, you can manage all documents in the system.

title: Access documents in specific folders
body: You can't view all documents in the system directly. To see all documents in a folder, select a folder from the drop-down menu in the top left of the Documents tab. If the folder you select has sub-folders, you can access them in the drop-down menu. For example, to see the documents of a specific contact, select the "/Contacts" folder and then the folder of the contact. To return to the root folder, select empty or "/" in the drop-down.

title: Search documents in the system
body: You can search for documents on different levels:

title: Search documents in the system
body: To search within a specific folder, select the folder by name in the drop-down menu.

title: Search documents in the system
body: To search from all documents in the system, select the root folder (empty or "/") in the drop-down menu.

title: Search documents in the system
body: You can make your search more specific with search criteria:

title: Search documents in the system
body: Document name: Search for exact (case sensitive) or partial matches. For partial matches (beginning, middle, or end of a file name), use * or %. For example, "Contract*", "*Contract*" or "*Contract", respectively.

title: Search documents in the system
body: Document tags: Select tags to search with. This returns all documents with any of the selected tags.

title: Search documents in the system
body: You can also filter the search results further by document name, modification date, time, and user, and tags.

title: Mass-modify documents
body: You can use the mass-modify functionality, for example, to categorize large numbers of documents quickly using tags. The following options are available at the bottom of the Documents tab:

title: Mass-modify documents
body: Delete document: Deletes all documents currently visible.

title: Mass-modify documents
body: Tag documents: Allows you to add or remove tags from all currently visible documents.

title: Add trade orders
body: You can create trade orders from scratch or based on a portfolio position, for example, to sell or buy a security already in your portfolio. You can also create trade orders based on a position in multiple portfolios for partial redemptions or security switches.

title: Add trade orders
body: Adding a trade order in a portfolio doesn't affect portfolio positions. Portfolio positions and cash amounts are recalculated when a transaction is accepted.

title: Add a trade order from scratch
body: To create a trade order from scratch, do the following:

title: Add a trade order from scratch
body: In the Overview, select the portfolio in which you want to add a trade order. If you select the portfolio first, the trade order is directly linked to the correct portfolio.

title: Add a trade order from scratch
body: Click New trade order in the New menu (top left) and select a security type.

title: Add a trade order from scratch
body: Fill in the fields in the Trade order window. For descriptions of the fields, see Trade order window in FA Back reference.

title: Add a trade order from scratch
body: Save the trade order.

title: Add a position-based trade order in a selected portfolio
body: To create a new trade order based on the position in the selected portfolio, do the following:

title: Add a position-based trade order in a selected portfolio
body: In the Overview, right-click the position row and select New.

title: Add a position-based trade order in a selected portfolio
body: Select Trade order with position's security and amount.

title: Add a position-based trade order in a selected portfolio
body: Fill in the fields. For descriptions of the fields, see Trade order window in FA Back reference.

title: Add a position-based trade order in a selected portfolio
body: Save the trade order.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: You can create trade orders based on a position in multiple portfolios, for example, to do partial redemptions or switches from one security to another using the reinvest option.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: To create trade orders based on the position in multiple portfolios, do the following:

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: In the Positions view, search for a position to use as a starting point.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Click Create transactions and fill in the fields in the Generate transactions from positions window:

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Create: The type of object to create. Select "Trade orders".

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Transaction type: The transaction type to use. The list of available types depends on the selected security.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Execution method: The trade order execution method.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Amount: The amount as percentage of the original position size.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Unit price: The unit price to use in the trade orders. Enter a question mark to get the latest price available in the system.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Transaction date

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Settlement date

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Tags: The tags for the trade orders.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: If the selected transaction type has a positive cash effect, reinvest by clicking Add security and filling in the fields, including the security to reinvest in. You can reinvest into multiple securities.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Click Preview trade orders to check the trade orders to be created. You can uncheck trade orders you don't want the system to create.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Click Confirm.

title: Model portfolio
body: A model portfolio is a basket of investments defined in terms of the securities and their shares. Model portfolios are used for rebalancing.

title: Model portfolio
body: There are two ways to define a model portfolio in FA:

title: Model portfolio
body: Define a model portfolio with fluctuating content and shares. Such a model is created as a regular portfolio linked to a model portfolio. To define the content and shares, create a regular portfolio and add positions in it. In the Model portfolio window, link the portfolio to a model portfolio by selecting it in the Linked portfolio field. To change the content of the model portfolio, record appropriate transactions to the linked portfolio in order to alter the securities or shares in it.

title: Model portfolio
body: Define a model portfolio with fixed content and shares. Set the date in the Date field from which the model portfolio is valid from and define the securities the model portfolio consists of and the shares of these securities of the model portfolio total. If you want to change the contents of the model portfolio, add a new date with new securities and shares.

title: Create a model portfolio
body: You can create a model portfolio manually or by importing it. To learn more about importing model portfolios, see File formats for importing model portfolios in FA Back reference.

title: Create a model portfolio
body: To create a model portfolio manually, do the following:

title: Create a model portfolio
body: Open the Rebalance view and click Model portfolio at the bottom of the veiw.

title: Create a model portfolio
body: Click Add and fill in the fields. For the field descriptions, see Model portfolio window in FA Back reference.

title: Create a model portfolio
body: Click Save.

title: Create a model portfolio
body: After you create a model portfolio, you can use it for rebalancing (see Rebalance). If you want to rebalance your portfolios against a combination of model portfolios (for example 20% of stock portfolio and 80% of bond portfolio), see Create a composite investment plan.

title: Related links
body: Model portfolio window in FA Back reference

title: Related links
body: File formats for importing model portfolios in FA Back reference

title: Rebalance methods
body: FA platform lets you set multiple rebalancing parameters to control how the rebalancing logic calculates what to buy and sell. You can combine the parameters in various ways. Below are the most common rebalance methods, with the parameters to use for each of them.

title: Conservative rebalance
body: With conservative rebalancing, you can purchase securities using only the cash in the portfolio account. You can realign the portfolio with the model in two rounds. In the first round, the system sells the excess positions above the target and buys with the available cash. After executing the sells and acquiring cash, the second round buys additional positions with the newly available cash to rebalance the portfolio fully.

title: Conservative rebalance
body: Existing outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") affect conservative rebalancing in the following way:

title: Conservative rebalance
body: Buy trade orders with negative cash effect reduce the available cash to reserve cash for buys.

title: Conservative rebalance
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type for the same security are taken into account when the system suggests new trade orders. If you should buy something but you already have a buy trade order for that security, or if you should sell but already have a sell trade order for the security, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Conservative rebalance
body: Example: You would need to buy Security A for 100 €, but you already have a trade order to buy Security A for 40 €. Rebalancing would create a buy trade order worth 100 € - 40 € = 60 €.

title: Conservative rebalance
body: To apply the conservative rebalance method, choose "Conservative (buy only with extra cash in portfolio)" in the Rebalance method field in the Rebalance window. Do not restrict rebalancing to accounts.

title: Full rebalance
body: With full rebalancing, you can buy securities using both available cash and the cash expected from suggested sales. This method calculates buys based on the estimated cash you will have after executing suggested sales with the latest market prices. With full rebalance, you can realign your entire portfolio against the model in one go.

title: Full rebalance
body: This method requires careful trade order management to ensure you settle your trades promptly, so you have sufficient cash available to complete your purchases. To mitigate the risk, you can set a limit on the cash from sells to use for buys during a full rebalance. For example, instead of counting sell values at 100%, you can count them at 90% or 95%. This conservative method ensures that even if prices drop between rebalancing and executing your sales, you'll likely still have enough cash to complete your buys. See Preference - Portfolios for details.

title: Full rebalance
body: Existing outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") affect full rebalancing in the following way:

title: Full rebalance
body: Buy trade orders with negative cash effect reduce the available cash to reserve cash for buys.

title: Full rebalance
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type for the same security are taken into account when the system suggests new trade orders. If you should buy something but you already have a buy trade order for that security, or if you should sell but already have a sell trade order for the security, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Full rebalance
body: Example: You would need to buy Security A for 100 €, but you already have a trade order to buy Security A for 40 €. Rebalancing would create a buy trade order worth 100 € - 40 € = 60 €.

title: Full rebalance
body: To apply this method, choose "Full (buy both with extra cash in portfolio and cash from sells)" in the Rebalance method field in the Rebalance window. Do not restrict rebalancing to accounts.

title: Full rebalance including outstanding orders
body: With full rebalance including outstanding orders, you can purchase securities using available cash, expected cash from recommended sells, and cash from outstanding trade orders with a positive cash effect (all statuses except "Open"), such as deposits and sells. Full rebalancing estimates available cash that will be received after executing all sells with the latest market prices. This method requires careful trade order management to ensure sufficient cash is available to complete your buys.

title: Full rebalance including outstanding orders
body: Before rebalancing, the system calculates expected positions. It sells any expected excess positions and buys with the cash expected to be available after executing these orders.

title: Full rebalance including outstanding orders
body: With full rebalance including outstanding trade orders, you can realign your entire portfolio at once, considering the effect of outstanding orders.

title: Full rebalance including outstanding orders
body: To apply this method, choose "Full including orders (also buy with cash from orders)" in the Rebalance method field in the Rebalance window. Do not restrict rebalancing to accounts.

title: Exchange
body: With exchange, you can sell a portfolio position that is above the target and buy a position that is below the target with the cash you expect to get from selling. The cash received from sells is estimated based on the latest market prices, putting pressure on your trade order management to ensure you settle your sell so that you have enough cash available to execute your buy.

title: Exchange
body: Existing outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") are considered in the exchange.

title: Exchange
body: Buy trade orders with negative cash effect reduce the available cash to reserve cash for buys. (However, exchange will not use the your cash balance for the suggested trade orders).

title: Exchange
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type for the same security are taken into account when the system suggests new trade orders. If you should buy something but you already have a buy trade order for that security, or if you should sell but already have a sell trade order for the security, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Exchange
body: Example: You would need to buy Security A for 100 €, but you already have a trade order to buy Security A for 40 €. Rebalancing would create a buy trade order worth 100 € - 40 € = 60 €.

title: Exchange
body: You can swap one position for another without rebalancing your entire portfolio. This process sells positions above the target and uses the proceeds to buy positions below the target. The weights of the positions ensure the new position matches the investment weight of the old one.

title: Exchange
body: To apply this method:

title: Exchange
body: Choose "Exchange (buy only with cash from sells)" in the Rebalance method field in the Rebalance window. Do not restrict rebalancing to accounts.

title: Exchange
body: Select the positions you want to exchange.

title: Invest cash
body: With the invest cash method, you can only use the excess cash in your account to buy securities, without making any other changes. It calculates purchases based on the available cash but does not involve selling any positions.

title: Invest cash
body: To apply this method:

title: Invest cash
body: Choose Restrict rebalancing to accounts in the Rebalance window. This ensures that rebalancing will only buy with the excess cash you have, but will not sell anything.

title: Invest cash
body: Choose "Conservative (buy both with extra cash in portfolio" in the Rebalance method field in the Rebalance window.

title: Cover for cash
body: With the cover-for-cash method, you can only use sells to address a negative account balance without making any other changes to your portfolio. It calculates the necessary sells to reach your target cash level without generating additional sells or making any purchases. The rebalancing process only sells enough to cover the negative balance, preventing excess cash in the account, which this method aims to avoid.

title: Cover for cash
body: This method lets you sell a portion of your holdings to cover for a negative account balance, for example after withdrawing fees from the portfolio, without realigning the entire portfolio.

title: Cover for cash
body: To apply this method, choose Restrict rebalancing to accounts in the Rebalance window. This ensures that rebalancing will only sell to cover for the negative cash you have, but will not buy anything.

title: Model change
body: With the model change, you can update your portfolio model by selling the securities from the old model and investing everything into the securities in the new model.

title: Model change
body: You have the option to execute a model change either as Conservative rebalancing or Full rebalancing, depending on whether you prefer to do it gradually or all at once. Regardless of the method chosen, rebalancing will sell off your old positions entirely and reinvest the proceeds into the new positions.

title: Rebalance portfolios against a model portfolio
body: You can use model portfolios to keep the customers' investment portfolios in balance.

title: Step 1 - Link the investment portfolios to the model portfolios
body: To link the customer's investment portfolio to a model portfolio, do the following:

title: Step 1 - Link the investment portfolios to the model portfolios
body: Select the customer's portfolio and open the Portfolio window.

title: Step 1 - Link the investment portfolios to the model portfolios
body: Select the model portfolio in the Basic info tab, Model portfolio field.

title: Step 1 - Link the investment portfolios to the model portfolios
body: Click Save.

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: To rebalance the investment portfolios against model portfolios and create trade orders:

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Depending on your business case, choose one of the options to rebalance investment portfolios:

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Rebalance a single portfolio. Select the investment portfolio on the Overview. Right-click it on the right and choose Rebalancing.

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Rebalance all investment portfolios linked to a model portfolio. Use one of the options to open the Rebalance window:

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Click Rebalancing on the Rebalance view and select the model portfolio you want to use.

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Click the Rebalancing button in the Model portfolio window for the model portfolio you want to use.

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Choose the investment portfolios you want to rebalance in the table.

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Rebalance selected portfolios against the model portfolios linked to them. Search the investment portfolios on the Portfolios view, click Rebalance at the bottom and select one of the options that include "Model portfolio" in the Rebalance against field.

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Define rebalancing parameters for affected portfolios, the rebalancing logic, and trade order generation options. If needed, adjust the security shares in the model portfolios in the table. For more information about the fields, see Rebalance window. Once you defined all parameters, click Rebalance.

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: View the trade orders suggested by the system. Use the filters at the top to adjust the list of trade orders. Once you are satisfied with the list, click Save.

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Note that only visible trade orders are saved. To save all suggested trade orders, clear all filters before saving.

title: Step 3 - Execute the trade orders to create transactions
body: To execute the trade orders:

title: Step 3 - Execute the trade orders to create transactions
body: Search for the created trade orders in the Trade orders view and set their status to "Executable". Send the executable trade orders forward to buy and sell securities to the investment portfolios.

title: Step 3 - Execute the trade orders to create transactions
body: Once the trades are implemented in the market, execute trade orders in FA with the realized values to create transactions to the investment portfolios.

title: Related links
body: Model portfolio management in FA Back reference

title: Related links
body: File formats for importing model portfolios in FA Back reference

title: Rebalance portfolios against the investment plan
body: You can use an investment plan to keep your investment portfolios in balance. Follow the steps below to rebalance your investment portfolios against their investment plans.

title: Step 1 - Rebalance your investment portfolios in order to get trade orders to buy or sell to match your investment portfolios to their investment plans
body: To rebalance investment portfolios against the investment plan and create trade orders:

body: Rebalance a single portfolio. Select the investment portfolio on the Overview. Right-click it on the right and choose Rebalancing.

title: Step 1 - Rebalance your investment portfolios in order to get trade orders to buy or sell to match your investment portfolios to their investment plans
body: Rebalance selected portfolios against the investment plans linked to them. Search the investment portfolios on the Portfolios view, click Rebalance at the bottom, and select one of the options that include "Investment plan" in the Rebalance against field.

title: Step 1 - Rebalance your investment portfolios in order to get trade orders to buy or sell to match your investment portfolios to their investment plans
body: Define rebalancing parameters for affected portfolios, the rebalancing logic, and trade order generation options. If needed, adjust the security shares in the investment plans in the table. For more information about the fields, see Rebalance window. Once you defined all parameters, click Rebalance.

title: Step 1 - Rebalance your investment portfolios in order to get trade orders to buy or sell to match your investment portfolios to their investment plans

title: Update contact information with Roaring
body: You can get up-to-date contact information from local authorities in Finland and Sweden by using the Roaring integration.

title: Prerequisites
body: You need an agreement with Roaring to use the integration. Roaring can guide you through getting the necessary agreements and permits.

title: Prerequisites
body: The contacts whose information you want to fetch must have their social security numbers stored as the Contact ID in FA Back.

title: Setting up
body: To set up the Roaring connection, see Set up Roaring connection.

title: Running contact information updates
body: To update contact information using the Roaring integration, go to the Contacts view, search for the contacts whose information you want to update, and select Roaring.io → Update from Finnish population register or Roaring.io → Update from Swedish population register at the bottom of the view.

title: Running contact information updates
body: The following fields in the Contact window are updated:

title: Running contact information updates
body: Name

title: Running contact information updates
body: Address

title: Running contact information updates
body: The following fields are updated only from the Swedish population register:

title: Running contact information updates
body: Tag group Deregistration is updated with the official reason code if the contact has been removed from the population register. The reason codes are listed on the Roaring website.

title: Running contact information updates
body: Key figure Death date is updated with the death date of a deceased person. This is accompanied by the Deregistration tag AV.

title: Running contact information updates
body: Key figure Guardian is updated with the social security number of the contact's legal guardian and the date of validity.

title: Overview
body: Overview allows you to manage your customer's portfolios, providing you with the tools to view customer's investments and access or modify all relevant information.

title: Overview
body: Overview consists of two sections. The tables on the left show the contents and transactions of a selected portfolio(s). The panel on the right allows you to change between selected portfolios and to view certain portfolio, contact or group information.

title: Overview
body: Overview is customizable to your user name, and all the choices you make on the visible sections are saved for your user name and remembered when you log in the next time. For example, whether the panel on the right is shown or hidden is remembered for your user name: if you choose to hide the info panel in your latest session, opening FA again will open Overview with the panel hidden.

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: At the top of the tab you can:

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: Search for the portfolio, customer or group you want to view on the tab. In the menu, the customers, portfolios and groups saved in the system with the status Active (Passive and Closed customers or portfolios cannot be chosen) are listed in the following order:

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: Groups listed first in the >Group Name form.

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: Customers and portfolios are listed second in alphabetical order: customers in the form Customer Name (ID) and portfolios in the form Customer Name - Portfolio Name (ID). In the listing, the customer is shown first, below which the active portfolios of this customer are shown. Passive and closed portfolios are not shown in the listing, and passive and closed customers are listed at the end of the listing in alphabetical order only if they have active portfolios.

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: The Other portfolios section at the end includes all the portfolios saved to the system without a link to a portfolio customer. These portfolios are listed in the form Portfolio Name (ID).

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: Quickly modify the selected group, customer or portfolio with the edit icon .

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: Choose the date you want to view to portfolio contents for.

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: The icons on the right let you:

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: Refresh the contents visible on the Overview to take into account all changes .

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: Open the Report window to print out a report for your selection .

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: Export the portfolio contents/positions in a PDF or Excel file .

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: Select the columns the position information is displayed in - see the descriptions of the available columns at Available columns for positions listings.

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: Hide the Info pane on the right .

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: You can use your browser’s back and forward buttons to browse between the selections you have made on the Overview during your session. Every time you select a group, customer or portfolio, your browser’s URL reflects your selection - as a result, the back button takes you back to your previous selection. (Available from FA 3.6 onward)

title: Positions
body: The upper section on the left shows the contents or the positions in the selected portfolio(s).

title: Positions
body: If you choose a customer or a group, Positions shows the total or aggregated content and positions of all the portfolios of the customer or in the group. The positions are based on calculating purchase lots of the securities in the portfolio: when modifications are made to the transactions in the portfolio, the contents shown are instantly up to date.

title: Positions
body: The positions in the portfolio are divided into Securities (further grouped by security types) and Accounts (further arranged into cash accounts, credit accounts, and other accounts). Below each section, you can find Securities total, Securities total inc. accrued interest, Cash accounts total, Credit accounts total, Accounts total, Accounts total inc. accrued interest, and Portfolio total.

title: Right-clicking a position
body: Right-clicking the Overview allows you to select how positions are shown on the Overview:

title: Right-clicking a position
body: Show positions. By default, all the individual, security level positions are shown. However, you can also choose to hide the security level positions under the security type headers. To collapse positions, right-click the Overview and deselect the Show positions selection. To show the hidden positions, right-click the Overview and select Show positions. Collapsing the positions allows you to effectively view large portfolios. Whether the positions are hidden or shown is remembered for your user name: if you choose to hide the positions in your latest session, opening FA again will open the Overview with hidden positions.

title: Right-clicking a position
body: Show extended position info. The Overview allows you to see the effect of unsettled transactions and unexecuted trade orders on your positions. Positions are highlighted with red and marked with a symbol to indicate that the position is affected by unsettled transactions (marked with a circle) and/or unexecuted trade orders (marked with a star). Moving your mouse over a marked row shows you more information on the effects, including the current position, effects, and the position afterwards. For accounts, the unsettled transactions are shown as upcoming cash flows, and for portfolio total, you can see the overall effect of your trade orders on your portfolio. This feature is by default enabled, but you can choose to hide the extended position information by right-clicking the Overview and deselecting the Show extended position info selection - to show the extended position information, right-click the Overview and select Show extended position info. See more detailed instructions through Extended position information on the Overview.

title: Right-clicking a position
body: Right-clicking a position on the Overview allows you to perform the following features related to the position:

title: Right-clicking a position
body: Open security. Opens the position's security in the Security window, where you can view and modify the security information. The same functionality can be accessed by double clicking a position related to a security.

title: Right-clicking a position
body: Open security's linked portfolio. Opens the position's security's linked portfolio on the Overview. This allows you to easily access for example a fund portfolio through a fund position. The selection is available if your position’s security has a linked portfolio, and you are allowed to access it in terms of limited visibility. If you want to easily see which positions have a linked portfolio, select Security linked portfolio as a column on the Overview. (Available from FA 3.6 onward).

title: Right-clicking a position
body: Open security information (URL). Opens the URL defined in the security information as a new browser tab.

title: Right-clicking a position
body: Search positions from other portfolios. Makes a position search on the Positions view for all portfolios with the selected security and date.

title: Right-clicking a position
body: New transaction/New trade order. Opens a pre-filled Transaction window to create a new transaction or new trade order based on the selected position. For account positions, you can create new cash transactions. Choose to create New.

title: Right-clicking a position
body: Transaction with position's security and amount - Portfolio, security and amount are pre-filled based on the selected position, and transaction date is set to be the current date.

title: Right-clicking a position
body: Transaction with position's security, amount and trade amount - Portfolio, security, amount, unit price, costs / taxes and trade amount are pre-filled based on the selected position, and transaction date is set to be the current date.

title: Right-clicking a position
body: Trade order with position's security and amount - portfolio, security and amount are pre-filled based on the selected position, and transaction date is set to be the current date.

title: Right-clicking a position
body: Processes. Launches any process against a position through the right-click menu.

title: Transactions and trade orders
body: The lower section of the Overview tab shows the transactions and/or open and executable trade orders in the portfolio (including trade order statuses Open, Accepted, Executable, Sent to execution, In execution, Executed in the market and Settled in the market) - by default the listing shows both transactions and trade orders. A star in the first column indicates an open or executable trade order in the listing. The selection of whether to show Transactions, Trade orders or All can be made from the first drop-down of the search fields.

title: Transactions and trade orders
body: By default, the transactions are shown ordered by the transaction date, newest first. You can also change this order by clicking one of the column headers: the arrow next to the column header indicates that the transactions are ordered based on the values in that column. In addition, you can use the search fields to search for transactions, or to filter the transactions shown with the columns you have selected to be visible on the Transactions listing through the column selection icon - see also Available columns for positions listings.

title: Show transaction/trade orders related to a position or an account
body: You can also view only the transactions/trade orders related to a certain position or account. This is possible by clicking a position or an account from the position listing - after this, only the transactions/trade orders related to the chosen security or account are listed in the Transactions sections. When clicking a position/account, the following transaction/trade orders are listed:

title: Show transaction/trade orders related to a position or an account
body: Transactions that have the clicked security as transaction's security.

title: Show transaction/trade orders related to a position or an account
body: Transactions that have the clicked account as transaction's account.

title: Show transaction/trade orders related to a position or an account
body: Transactions that have the clicked security as transaction's second security (for example, if there are exchanges, those are shown when clicking on either of the positions involved).

title: Show transaction/trade orders related to a position or an account
body: Transactions that have the clicked security's linked security as transaction's security (for example, when clicking on a future cashflow position will also show the contract related to it) (Available from FA 3.7 onward).

title: Hiding transactions from the Overview
body: You can hide certain transactions from the Overview’s transaction listing. You can do this by marking your transaction as Hidden – hidden transactions still affect your positions, but they are not shown on the Overview’s transaction listing. This allows you to filter the Overview to only show transactions you need in your day-to-day work to get an overview of your client’s investments, while you can access other transactions through the Transactions view. This is especially useful for bookkeeping transactions, such as deferrals or value adjustments, which don’t affect how much you own, but only alter the position’s values for bookkeeping purposes.

title: Right-clicking a transaction
body: To Modify or Delete a transaction or a trade order, right-click it. You can select multiple transactions or trade orders by holding the Ctrl key. The changes are then applied to all of the selected items.

title: Portfolio hierarchy
body: The upper section on the left shows the contents or the positions in the selected portfolio(s):

title: Portfolio hierarchy
body: If you have selected a portfolio or customer, the portfolio hierarchy shows the customer and all the portfolios of the customer. If the customer shown is marked as a contact in another customer's portfolio, this another customer and the portfolio are shown below the customer's portfolios.

title: Portfolio hierarchy
body: If you have selected a group, the portfolio hierarchy shows the portfolios within the chosen group, grouping the portfolios under their customers.

title: Portfolio hierarchy
body: Your selection is shown with a blue background. Customers and portfolios are shown in alphabetical order based on the name.

title: Portfolio hierarchy
body: The portfolio hierarchy section is limited to show only certain number of portfolios, by default 500. You can configure in Portfolios Preferences how many portfolios are shown in the tree. The title of the section indicates how many portfolios the tree is showing if your selection exceeds the maximum. This is relevant if you select a group with more than the number of portfolios show, all of them won't be shown within the tree. However, the entire selected group is included when showing the aggregated positions.

title: Portfolio hierarchy
body: Portfolio hierarchy allows you to perform certain actions through right-clicking a level in the tree:

title: Portfolio hierarchy
body: Open group / Open contact / Open portfolio. Opens the chosen group / contact / portfolio in the corresponding window, where you can view and modify the information. The same functionality can be accessed by double-clicking an item in the tree.

title: Portfolio hierarchy
body: Close portfolio. Allows you to close the selected portfolio for bookkeeping purposes. Closing a portfolio is related to balancing the books: the portfolio is closed at the end of each accounting period and is re-opened at the beginning of the accounting period. The portfolio closing is defined by setting the close date, closing method (No change, Depreciation, Depreciation and refund or Market value) and the transaction types for the Remove and Add transactions to be created for closing the portfolio. Selecting a transaction type for only Remove or Add supports closing a portfolio with only one transaction type.

title: Portfolio hierarchy
body: Rebalancing. Opens the Rebalance window for rebalancing the selected portfolio.

title: Portfolio hierarchy
body: New portfolio / New transaction / New trade order / New contract. Allows you to create a new portfolio for your contact or a new transaction, trade order or contract in your portfolio.

title: Portfolio hierarchy
body: Processes. Launches any process against a position through the right-click menu.

title: Memo
body: The second info panel shows the comments and notes written for the selected customer or portfolio. The information is defined in the Memo tab of the Portfolio or Contact window: the Memo shows the text written in the fields Memo, Description, Info 2 and Info 3.

title: Memo
body: You can modify the memo by clicking it once, making the desired modifications and confirming the changes when navigating away. Portfolio or customer memos can be also be modified in the Memo tab on the Portfolio or Contact window - double-clicking the memo panel opens the correct window for modifications. It is also possible to import text to the Memo from an external text file from Import - Import memos.

title: Memo
body: In Memo, the different tab sheets contain information for both the customer (the first, left-hand side tab) and the selected portfolio (the following tab). The mark * next to the customer or portfolio ID in the tab sheet heading indicates that the memo has some content. If the customer and the portfolio have the same ID, it is good to remember that the customer memo is always under the farthest left tab sheet.

title: Portfolio / Contact / Group basic info
body: You can use the third info panel to view the basic information of the chosen portfolio, contact or dynamic group. The information shown corresponds to the information defined on the Basic info tab sheet on the Portfolio or Contact window or the dynamic group information defined on the Groups view.

title: Portfolio / Contact / Group basic info
body: The portfolio or contact information can be accessed from the edit button on the top-right corner of the basic info panel, or by searching the portfolio or customer from the Portfolios or Contacts view.

title: Documents
body: You can use the fourth info panel to view the documents of the chosen contact or portfolio. The documents can be managed through the Documents section of the info panel: you can view the documents, edit them, or add new documents to your chosen contact or portfolio from the Overview.

title: Key figures for contacts, portfolios and securities
body: Configurable key figures allow you to define what key figure values you want to store on your contacts, portfolios and securities. Key figures allow you to store a time series of values of your choice. For example, you can store fee percentages that change over time to your portfolios, or your key figure on your instruments, extending the possibilities of storing data into FA.

title: Model portfolio window
body: Model portfolio preferences allow you to define model portfolio that are used to keep your investment portfolio in balance (see Rebalance portfolios against a model portfolio).

title: Model portfolio window
body: Existing model portfolios are listed by name on the left side of the Model portfolio window. To modify a model portfolio, select it from the list. To add a new model portfolio, click Add model portfolio.

title: Model portfolio information
body: The model portfolio information, both for fluctuating or fixed content, is defined in the fields at the right side of the window: a red star indicates a mandatory field. You can only define either fluctuating or fixed content, not both.

title: Model portfolio information
body: Available fields are:

title: Model portfolio information
body: Name*

title: Model portfolio information
body: The name of the model portfolio, which enables the model portfolio to be identified easily.

title: Model portfolio information
body: Code*

title: Model portfolio information
body: The individual model portfolio code that separates it from other model portfolios.

title: Model portfolio information
body: Linked portfolio (only when defining fluctuating shares)

title: Model portfolio information
body: Portfolio that represents the model portfolio (created in the system as a regular portfolio). If the contents of the model portfolio are not defined in this window, and a portfolio is linked to the model portfolio, the contents of the linked portfolio are used as the model portfolio contents. Linking a portfolio to the model portfolio allows updating the model portfolio contents and shares by updating the portfolio linked to the model portfolio.

title: Model portfolio information
body: Number of portfolios the model portfolio is linked to:

title: Model portfolio information
body: The number of portfolios linked to the model portfolio. The number indicates, how many portfolios the model portfolio is linked to, and how many portfolios are rebalanced against this portfolio.

title: Model portfolio information
body: Restrict this model portfolio to be shown to roles

title: Model portfolio information
body: Restrict the access to this model portfolio to only certain user roles. The list of user roles includes:

title: Model portfolio information
body: User roles assigned in the FA Admin Console app (for details, see User details pane).

title: Model portfolio information
body: Underlying system-level roles marked with # before the role name.

title: Model portfolio information
body: Date (only when defining fixed shares)

title: Model portfolio information
body: The date from which the model portfolio is valid (usually the creation or start date of the portfolio). The model portfolio can be updated by adding a new date and re-defining the positions of the model portfolio below this date: the updated model portfolio is valid from the new date onward.

title: Model portfolio information
body: Allow the sum of model portfolio shares other than 100%

title: Model portfolio information
body: When enabled, the model portfolio shares does not have to add up to 100%, allowing you to define partial or leveraged models. If your model portfolio doesn't add up to 100%, you are presented with a question Positions in your model portfolio add up to xx %. Do you want to save your model portfolio even though it does not add up to 100 %? to prevent you from unintentionally saving non-complete model portfolios.

title: Model portfolio shares
body: The table shows the model portfolio content – securities and their target shares. To include the portfolio's cash in rebalancing, add the currency security as a position and specify the target share. For example, if you have EUR accounts in your portfolio and want to have 1% cash in euros, add the currency security EUR with a target share of 1%.

title: Model portfolio shares
body: Security

title: Model portfolio shares
body: Security in the model portfolio.

title: Model portfolio shares
body: Share %

title: Model portfolio shares
body: The share of security in the model portfolio.

title: Model portfolio shares
body: Min share %, Max share %

title: Model portfolio shares
body: Minimum and maximum share of the security.

title: Export model portfolio
body: You can export model portfolio details and model portfolio shares as a CSV file by clicking Export and selecting Model portfolio details or Model portfolio shares. You can only export the details or shares of one model portfolio at a time.

title: Export model portfolio
body: The file format is described in File formats for importing model portfolios.

title: Related links
body: Rebalance portfolios against a model portfolio in FA User guide

title: Rebalance window
body: You can create model portfolios or investment plans and use them to keep your investment portfolios in balance. Rebalancing creates trade orders to buy and sell securities according to the model. For general information about rebalancing approaches and for instructions, see Rebalance in FA User guide.

title: Rebalance window
body: The Rebalance window allows you to define the rebalance parameters and the securities to rebalance. The window lists securities in the portfolio or model portfolio/ investment plan linked to the rebalanced portfolio and indicates the shares of these securities in the investment portfolio and model. The portfolio account is also included in rebalancing.

title: Rebalance window
body: At the top of the Rebalance window, you can define the rebalancing parameters.

title: Affected portfolios
body: Affected portfolios

title: Affected portfolios
body: The Affected portfolios section defines which portfolios are rebalanced.

title: Affected portfolios
body: Rebalance against

title: Affected portfolios
body: The target for rebalancing, in the priority order: if the first one in the list is defined, it is used – otherwise, the one id used, and so on. The targets can be:

title: Affected portfolios
body: "Model portfolio", "Investment plan" – Model portfolio or investment plan linked to the portfolio.

title: Affected portfolios
body: "Portfolio itself" – Target shares you specify in the Rebalance window.

title: Affected portfolios
body: "Empty portfolio" – An option to empty the portfolio – this will set all the new shares as 0 % and sell everything away, regardless of the linked model or plan.

title: Affected portfolios
body: Include sub-porfolios

title: Affected portfolios
body: Aggregates positions and investment plan/ model portfolio contents also from the rebalanced portfolio's subportfolios. This allows you to divide holdings into subportfolios and rebalance everything at once through the main portfolio. Trade orders are created either to the main portfolio or the sub-portfolios based on which portfolio or portfolio's investment plan / model portfolio the trade order's security can be found in: for sells of existing positions, trade orders are created in the same portfolio where the position currently is, and for buys, trade orders are created in the same portfolio which has the position in the investment plan / model portfolio.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Rebalance parameters

title: Rebalance parameters
body: The Rebalance parameters section defines rebalancing logic.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Date

title: Rebalance parameters
body: The rebalancing date. This date affects:

title: Rebalance parameters
body: The market prices, rabalanced portfolio shares, trade order amounts. The percentage shares of securities in the portfolio are determined based on the market prices on the rebalancing date. The market prices on this date are used to calculate the amount in the suggested trade orders.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: The content of the model portfolio/ investment plan. The target shares are fetched based on the selected rebalancing date

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Restrict rebalancing to accounts

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Restrict rebalancing to only reach the target level for portfolio accounts, without any other buys or sells. This feature has different effects depending on the rebalance method (buying with extra cash or using cash from sells) – see Rebalance methods.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: With the conservative rebalancing method, securities are bought and sold only to achieve the target level of the account. If the account has excess cash, the selected securities (largest first) are bought as long as there is available cash but nothing is sold. If the account has a lack of cash, the selected securities (largest first) are sold until the account reaches the target level - nothing is bought and securities are sold only to rebalance the account to the defined level.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: With the exchange method, if the account balance is below the target, it is first rebalanced with sells. After this, the excess cash from sells is used to buy the securities to be rebalanced, but securities are sold only to cover all the necessary buys. If there are Executable sell trade orders, the cash coming in from these is taken into account when selling the securities.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: With full rebalance, if the account balance is below the target, it is first rebalanced with sells. After this, the excess cash from sells is used to buy the securities to be rebalanced, but securities are sold only to cover all the necessary buys.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: You can also define the rebalance settings in Preference ("Define target range for portfolio's cash balance", "Define how much negative cash balance is increased by to cover all negative cash" and "Define how much positive cash balance is decreased by to ensure positive cash balance"). These preferences determine how rebalancing tries to achieve the target level for accounts. See Preference - Portfolios for details.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Rabalance method

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Rebalancing approach: conservative rebalance, full rebalance, full rebalance including outstanding orders, exchange, invest cash, cover for cash, and model change (see Rebalance methods).

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Filter out small trade orders based on

title: Rebalance parameters
body: The minimum size for the trade orders that rebalancing should create. The size restrictions don't apply if you sell an entire position away from the portfolio (see Rebalance). Set the minimum difference between the portfolio position and the model as:

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Minimum change % (absolute/ percentage points)" - The difference in percentage points.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Minimum change % (relative / percentage change)" - The relative difference in percentage.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Minimum trade amount" - The minimum trade amount in portfolio currency. Alternatively, you can define a Minimum trade amount for each of your securities (see Security window).

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Position is within min/max share" - The difference defined with the minimum and maximum thresholds in the model. Trade orders are created only if your position deviates outside of the minimum and maximum thresholds. The minimum trade amount for each trade order is calculated as follows:

title: Rebalance parameters
body: For "buy": ( target share - min share ) * portfolio value

title: Rebalance parameters
body: For "sell": ( max share - target share ) * portfolio value

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Positions that don't have the thresholds specified int the model are rebalanced without filtering when "Position is within min/max share" is selected.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Use cash from accounts

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Accounts to use for buys if you select to buy with extra cash in the portfolio. This option allows you to keep your portfolio fully invested and exclude certain accounts (for example, accrued fee accounts) from rebalancing.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "All accounts" – Use cash on all accounts. You can choose to use available credit or repay the used credit (see the Use portfolio credit field below).

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Cash accounts" – Use cash on the accounts marked as "cash accounts" in the Portfolio window, Accounts tab.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Cash and credit accounts" – Use cash on cash and credit accounts. You can choose to use available credit or repay the used credit (see the Use portfolio credit field below).

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Default account only" – Use cash on the portfolio's default account – the first account in the list in the Portfolio window, Accounts tab. If this account is a credit account, you can choose to use available credit or repay the used credit (see the Use portfolio credit field below).

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Use portfolio credit

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Use credit account for buys. Choose if you want to use the positive account balance and available credit for buys, and if you want to cover the negative balance. The option is shown if you selected "All accounts", "Cash and credit accounts" or "Default account only" in Use cash from accounts.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Don't use portfolio credit" – Use only positive balance on the credit account for buys, without repaying the used credit.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Use portfolio credit" – Use available credit and positive balance on the credit account for buys, without repaying the used credit.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Repay portfolio credit" – Use positive balance on the credit account. In case of negative balance, rebalance the credit account account to 0. The cash is rebalanced to the default portfolio account, and you can then repay the credit manually. If a portfolio has no accounts other than the credit account, the credit is repaid automatically.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Calculate fees to trade orders

title: Rebalance parameters
body: An option to calculate fees, or to estimate the effect of an upcoming fee when generating buy and sell trade orders. If a fee is calculated, the effect of the fee is taken into account when determining how many units you can buy with you available cash and how much money you get from sells. This allows you to estimate the effects of upcoming transaction fees more accurately. Fees are also saved in the Fees field for each trade order.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Don't calculate fees" - Don't calculate fees in trade orders.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Calculate portfolio specific fees" - Calculate a transaction fee defined in the portfolio (Portfolio window, Fees tab).

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Calculate fixed fees" - Calculate a fee defined as a percentage in the field available next to the selection.

title: Trade order parameters
body: Trade order parameters

title: Trade order parameters
body: Trade order parameters section includes criteria for defining how trade orders are created

title: Trade order parameters
body: Set accounts to trade orders

title: Trade order parameters
body: An option to define accounts for trade orders (Account filed):

title: Trade order parameters
body: "Don't set accounts to trade orders" - Create trade orders with "No account".

title: Trade order parameters
body: "Set the default account to trade orders" - Set the portfolio's default account – the first account in the list in the Portfolio window, Accounts tab.

title: Trade order parameters
body: "Set the currency account (or default account) to trade orders" - Use the account with the same currency as the trade order. If such account doesn't exist, this option uses the default account of the portfolio. If the portfolio doesn't have accounts, then the shared accounts for the portfolio are used in the same order: first using the shared account with the same currency as the trade order, and if not found, then using the shared default account.

title: Trade order parameters
body: Create trade orders with status

title: Trade order parameters
body: The status of trade orders.

title: Trade order parameters
body: Set trade order tags

title: Trade order parameters
body: Tags to add to trade orders. For example, you can use tags to mark trade orders with execution instructions.

title: Trade order parameters
body: Set portfolio tags

title: Trade order parameters
body: Tags to add to portfolios affected by rebalancing. This allows you to for example mark the rebalanced portfolios.

title: Trade order parameters
body: Rebalance memo

title: Trade order parameters
body: Comments and notes on your rebalances, for example, references. Memos are stored in the Rebalance view, which allows you to search for conducted rebalances.

title: Summary of the rebalanced portfolios
